questions.subject: Infectiology and hygiene
questions.render_question: A previously healthy 6-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of irritability and poor feeding for 6 days. He has also not had a bowel movement in 9 days and has been crying less than usual. He is bottle fed with formula and his mother has been weaning him with mashed bananas mixed with honey for the last 3 weeks. His immunizations are up-to-date. He appears weak and lethargic. He is at the 50th percentile for length and 75th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows dry mucous membranes and delayed skin turgor. There is poor muscle tone and weak head control. Neurological examination shows ptosis of the right eye. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.render_hint: Considering the boy's poor feeding, lack of bowel movement, weak head control, and exposure to honey, he most likely has botulism. Infant botulism is caused by Clostridium botulinum, spores of which may be present in honey. C. botulinum produces a toxin that is absorbed from the gut into systemic circulation. This toxin blocks the release of acetylcholine from the motor end plate and thus causes neuromuscular blockade, leading to the symptoms seen here.

a.walk_why: Gentamicin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic that is used in mainly treating infections caused by aerobic gram-negative rods and may be indicated in newborns as empiric therapy of bacterial meningitis. Although this patient presents with some signs of infant meningitis (e.g., irritability, poor feeding), poor muscle tone and constipation would not be consistent with this diagnosis. He is also older than one month and thus no longer considered a newborn. Aminoglycosides are actually contraindicated in the case of botulism because they may exacerbate symptoms by causing neuromuscular blockade. Additionally, antibiotics in general cannot counter the effect of the botulinum toxins, nor are aminoglycosides effective against anaerobes, such as C. botulinum, anyway.

b.walk_why: Equine-derived antitoxins are immunoglobulins that are derived from the blood of horses that have been immunized with a specific bacterial toxin/toxoid (e.g., botulinum toxin). Equine-derived antitoxins contain foreign proteins that can cause severe allergic reactions in infants, and must therefore be avoided in cases of infant botulism.
b.walk_but: The equine-derived heptavalent botulism antitoxin may, however, be used in adults with wound botulism or food-borne botulism because the risk of hypersensitivity is lower in adults than in infants. They are also considerably cheaper than human-derived antitoxins.

c.walk_why: Penicillin is a beta-lactam antibiotic that is primarily used in treating some gram-positive aerobes, including Streptococcus pyogenes, Streptococcus pneumoniae, and Actinomyces. S. pneumoniae may cause meningitis, which often presents poor feeding and irritability in infants, but poor muscle tone and constipation would be inconsistent with this diagnosis. The goal of treatment is to counteract the effect of botulinum toxins. Since antibiotics cannot counteract the effect of botulinum toxins, intravenous penicillin is ineffective in the treatment of infant botulism.
c.walk_but: Some antibiotics may be considered in cases of infant botulism that are complicated by secondary bacterial infection and in cases of wound botulism.

d.walk_why: Plasmapheresis refers to the separation of plasma from blood in extracorporeal circulation. The plasma is then either exchanged with normal plasma or filtered to remove pathological antibodies, immune complexes, and/or protein-bound toxins. Plasmapheresis is also a therapeutic option for immune-mediated neurological conditions such as Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS). However, the diagnosis of GBS is also unlikely in this infant because GBS typically presents with ascending paralysis following certain gastrointestinal or respiratory tract infections.
d.walk_but: Infants with the Miller-Fischer variant of Guillain-Barre syndrome may, however, present with a similar pattern of descending paralysis. Many cases of botulism are often misdiagnosed as variants of Guillain-Barre syndrome.

e.walk_why: Human-derived antitoxins are immunoglobulins that are derived from the serum of individuals who have been immunized with a specific bacterial toxin/toxoid (e.g., botulinum toxin). Human-derived botulism immune globulin against the botulinum toxin is the treatment of choice for infant botulism because the risk of hypersensitivity is lower than with equine-derived antitoxins.
e.walk_but: In addition to antitoxin therapy, patients will also require extensive supportive care. The three most important supportive measures are: 1. Placing the infant supine with the head tilted back at 30° to prevent aspiration of secretions; 2. Early prophylactic intubation to maintain a patent airway and facilitate mechanical ventilation in the event of respiratory muscle weakness; 3. Nasogastric or nasojejunal tube feeding.

f.walk_why: Pyridostigmine is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, which is used to treat myasthenia gravis. Infants with congenital myasthenic syndromes and juvenile myasthenia gravis can also present with feeding difficulty, poor head control, and ptosis. However, the history of weaning with honey and the absence of a family history of myasthenia gravis suggest infant botulism as the more likely diagnosis.

questions.subject: Infectiology and hygiene
questions.render_question: A 29-year-old man comes to the physician because of a swollen right knee for 3 days. The patient reports that he has experienced similar episodes over the past several weeks. According to him, the swelling would last approximately 5 days and affected the right knee and sometimes the left elbow as well. He has a history of a skin rash that subsided two months ago. He lives in Connecticut with his wife and works as a landscaper. His temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a tender and warm right knee; range of motion is limited by pain. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. His hematocrit is 44%, leukocyte count is 10,300/mm³, and platelet count is 145,000/mm3. Serum electrolyte concentrations are within normal limits. Arthrocentesis is performed and the synovial fluid is cloudy. Gram stain is negative. Analysis of the synovial fluid shows a leukocyte count of 70,000/mm³ and 80% neutrophils. Serologic testing confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.render_hint: Based on the patient's history of rash and recurrent episodic knee problems, as well as the fact that he works outside in Connecticut, he most likely has Lyme arthritis.

a.walk_why: Osteoarthritis is a disabling joint condition caused by degeneration of articular cartilage that occurs with prolonged use and age. It commonly affects the knees. However, rather than having an episodic, migratory course, as is the case in this patient, pain associated with osteoarthritis remains in the affected joints and typically worsens toward the end of the day or following physical activity. This patient also does not represent the typical age group affected by osteoarthritis, a condition that occurs in older age (i.e., in individuals > 65 years) The arthrocentesis findings here indicate an infectious process, and the history of skin rash and outdoor occupation make Lyme arthritis the most likely cause.

b.walk_why: Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of septic arthritis. Unlike the case here, septic arthritis typically involves infection of a single joint (i.e., monoarthritis) and is characterized by an acute onset and course. The arthrocentesis findings in this case do point toward an infectious process, but the negative Gram stain and history of skin rash make Lyme arthritis more likely.

c.walk_why: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory autoimmune disorder that leads to the progressive destruction of cartilage and bone. RA is of unknown etiology and is characterized by morning stiffness and symmetrical joint involvement, which this patient does not have. It is also associated with many extra-articular manifestations, which are not present in this patient. Another difference is that synovial fluid analysis in RA usually shows a leukocyte count of < 50,000/mm3.

d.walk_why: Neisseria gonorrhoeae is the most common cause of septic arthritis in sexually active young adults as a result of disseminated disease. Unlike the case here, septic arthritis typically involves infection of a single joint (i.e., monoarthritis) and is characterized by an acute onset and course. The arthrocentesis findings here do point toward an infectious process, but the patient’s history of skin rash and outdoor occupation make Lyme arthritis more likely. Serology is not typically used to diagnose gonococcal arthritis.

e.walk_why: Borrelia burgdorferi is a tick-borne spirochete bacteria that causes Lyme disease and is the most likely cause of this patient’s joint complaints. He lives in an endemic area for Lyme disease (i.e., the Northeast), has an occupation that regularly exposes him to ticks, and had a skin rash (i.e., erythema chronicum migrans) that subsided one month before. This history in combination with a migratory and intermittent polyarthritis in the large joints one month later should raise suspicion of early disseminated Lyme disease. The nonspecific arthrocentesis findings of negative Gram stain and leukocytosis with increased neutrophils are consistent with Lyme arthritis. At this point, two-step serological testing is indicated to confirm the diagnosis: The screening test ELISA should be followed by a confirmatory Western blot test to detect IgG and IgM antibodies against Borrelia.
e.walk_but: The treatment for Lyme arthritis in adults is oral doxycycline.

f.walk_why: Campylobacter jejuni is one of the causative organisms of reactive arthritis. Reactive arthritis is an autoimmune condition that can lead to arthritis accompanied by conjunctivitis and urethritis. It typically occurs after a bacterial infection of the gastrointestinal or urinary tract. However, this patient has no additional eye or urinary symptoms, nor does he report a recent gastrointestinal infection. The arthrocentesis findings here indicate an infectious process, but the negative Gram stain and history of skin rash make Lyme arthritis the most likely cause.

questions.subject: Cardiology and angiology
questions.render_question: A 12-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of high fever and left ankle and knee joint swelling. She had a sore throat 3 weeks ago. There is no family history of serious illness. Her immunizations are up-to-date. She had an episode of breathlessness and generalized rash when she received dicloxacillin for a skin infection 2 years ago. She appears ill. Her temperature is 38.8°C (102.3°F), pulse is 87/min, and blood pressure is 98/62 mm Hg. Examination shows left ankle and knee joint swelling and tenderness; range of motion is limited. Breath sounds over both lungs are normal. A grade 3/6 holosytolic murmur is heard best at the apex. Abdominal examination is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.render_hint: This patient is presenting with valvulitis and polyarthritis (2 of the Jones major criteria). Furthermore, the girl had a recent sore throat (presumably due to a group A streptococcus infection). Considered together, these features make acute rheumatic fever the most likely diagnosis. While you would normally give the patient penicillin, the hypersensitivity reaction to a penicillin class antibiotic two years ago should be considered when choosing treatment.

a.walk_why: Methotrexate, an antimetabolite, may be administered to treat, for example, certain cancers or in cases of rheumatic diseases (e.g., juvenile idiopathic arthritis). This young patient presents with polyarthritis, which is consistent with juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA). However, she does not have any extra-articular manifestations (e.g., uveitis, rashes, nail changes, lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly), ruling out JIA.

b.walk_why: Clarithromycin, a macrolide, may be administered in the case of sexually transmitted diseases (e.g., chlamydia), atypical pneumonia, or certain infections with gram-positive bacteria. Because this patient is allergic to oral penicillin V, the first-line treatment for rheumatic fever, macrolides would be a good alternative.

c.walk_why: Doxycycline, a tetracycline, is used to treat, e.g., Chlamydia and Rickettsia infections. Group A Streptococcus, the causative pathogen behind acute rheumatic fever, has developed widespread resistance to tetracyclines (up to 97% of S. pyogenes strains are resistant in some areas). Furthermore, when administered in children, tetracyclines may cause permanent tooth discoloration and photosensitivity. They are therefore not used when better alternatives are available.

d.walk_why: Glucocorticoids have many indications (e.g., autoimmune diseases, rheumatological conditions). They may be used to treat acute rheumatic fever in patients who are allergic to aspirin or should not take aspirin for other reasons. As this patient is only 12 years old and aspirin should not be administered in children with fever-causing illnesses (her temperature is 38.8°C (102.3°F)), glucocorticoids should be considered. However, only low-dose glucocorticoids would be indicated, not high-dose glucocorticoids (which have potentially more severe side effects).

e.walk_why: Amoxicillin is a beta-lactam aminopenicillin antibiotic used to treat infections with gram-positive and also some gram-negative pathogens. It is often used in the treatment of acute rheumatic fever and is at least as effective as penicillin. However, because penicillin and amoxicillin belong to the same class of drugs and the patient has a history of hypersensitivity reactions to penicillin, amoxicillin is contraindicated in this case.

f.walk_why: Ciprofloxacin, a fluoroquinolone, is mainly administered for urinary and gastrointestinal tract infections (especially if due to gram-negative organisms). Fluoroquinolones do cover a broad spectrum of pathogens, including streptococci. However, because they may damage developing cartilage and bones, they are generally only used in children < 18 years of age as an alternative treatment in narrowly defined scenarios.

g.walk_why: Vancomycin may be administered to treat serious infections with gram-positive pathogens (e.g., MRSA, Clostridium difficile). It is not part of the treatment regimen for acute rheumatic fever.

questions.subject: Infectiology and hygiene
questions.render_question:
A previously healthy 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of fever and pain in the left lower extremity. His mother says that he has refused to walk for the last two days and has had a poor appetite. He returned from a weekend camping trip about a month ago. His mother has rheumatoid arthritis and his maternal cousin died of osteosarcoma at the age of 12. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 80th percentile for height and 70th percentile for weight. He appears ill. His temperature is 39.3°C (102.7°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 95/50 mm Hg. Examination of the left hip shows tenderness; range of motion is limited. Minimal attempts to rotate the hip cause severe discomfort. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:















 Hemoglobin  12 g/dL Leukocyte count 19,800/mm3 Platelet count  254,000/mm3
 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate  55 mm/h Serum Glucose 80 mg/dL CRP 15 mg/L 
 X-ray of the pelvis shows a widened acetabular space on the left side. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.render_hint: This patient's fever, elevated inflammatory markers (leukocyte count, ESR, CRP), and x-ray findings indicate a bacterial infection of the hip (i.e., septic arthritis) that is restricting the movement of his hip.

a.walk_why: Doxycycline is a tetracycline antibiotic that is effective against atypical bacteria such as Borrelia, Rickettsia, and Chlamydia. Borrelia spp. cause Lyme disease, which commonly first presents with erythema migrans and can also cause hip pain later in disseminated disease (Lyme arthritis). Although a rash is not always present and a patient may not recall a tick bite, this patient went camping a month ago, which would not be enough time for lyme arthritis to develop. Additionally, the acute presentation, high fever, and imaging findings would not be expected in Lyme arthritis. Doxycycline would also be contraindicated in this patient because of its severe side effects in children (discoloration of the teeth, inhibition of bone growth).

b.walk_why: A bone biopsy would be indicated if imaging studies showed radiographic signs of malignancy (e.g., periosteal reactions such as a Sunburst appearance or Codman’s triangle). However, the widened acetabular space seen on this patient’s x-ray is indicative of excess fluid (e.g., an abscess) rather than malignancy. Since his presentation and labwork are already indicative of septic arthritis, a bone biopsy would not aid diagnosis or treatment.

c.answer: Synovial fluid drainage plus nafcillin and cefazolin therapy
c.walk_why: If septic arthritis is suspected, prompt synovial fluid drainage should be conducted (via arthrocentesis) and be followed by empiric therapy to minimize the risk of long-term joint complications. Antibiotics should cover S. aureus, the most common cause of septic arthritis. An appropriate regimen for this child, who has no history of hospitalization and therefore is unlikely to have an MRSA infection, would be nafcillin plus cefazolin.
c.walk_but: Drained synovial fluid should be sent for gram stain, culture, and susceptibility testing, and antibiotics should be tailored to the results when they become available. Patients with a high risk of MRSA infection should be given clindamycin, or vancomycin if signs of sepsis are present.

d.walk_why: Trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole (TMP/SMX) is an antibiotic combination made up of a dihydrofolate-reductase inhibitor (trimethoprim) and a sulfonamide antibiotic (sulfamethoxazole). TMP/SMX is commonly prescribed for urinary tract infections caused by E. coli and other gram-negative bacteria, as well as prophylaxis for opportunistic infections in HIV/AIDS patients. It is not commonly used in septic arthritis, which requires an antibiotic with gram-positive coverage including S. aureus.

e.walk_why: Vancomycin is an antibiotic with broad-spectrum coverage against gram-positive bacteria including MRSA. It would be part of the empiric treatment for septic arthritis if this patient had had a history of recent hospitalization or lived in an area with high MRSA prevalence. In addition, rapid reduction of both bacterial activity and pressure within the infected joint are important if long-term complications are to be avoided, and antibiotic therapy solely targets bacterial activity.

f.walk_why: Bedrest and acetaminophen would be the treatment for transient synovitis, a temporary inflammation of the hip joint common in children and often preceded by an upper respiratory tract infection. Transient synovitis presents with pain in the groin, hip, and/or knee, as well as a decreased range of motion in the hip because of pain, as in this patient. However, the laboratory and imaging findings are more consistent with septic arthritis.

g.walk_why: An MRI of the hip would provide high-resolution images particularly useful in investigating soft tissue pathologies, or if the diagnosis were unclear. However, the clinical picture in this patient is clear enough to warrant prompt initiation of therapy for septic arthritis first.
g.walk_but: MRI could be used later in septic arthritis to examine possible infectious involvement of the surrounding soft tissue. However, obtaining an MRI can be time-consumiing, especially as a 2-year-old would require sedation, and is therefore not a good first step.

h.walk_why: Arthroscopy is useful in diagnosing and repairing a wide variety of orthopedic conditions. It may also be used in septic arthritis, if the infection is located in a joint that is difficult to aspirate, such as the hip. However, arthroscopic drainage would only allow for joint decompression in this patient, and would not treat the underlying infection, which should also be addressed to avoid long-term complications.
h.walk_but: Arthroscopy might also be employed for septic arthritis for further investigation if there is no response to initial therapy, if soft tissue infection occurs, or if debridement is necessary.

questions.subject: Infectiology and hygiene
questions.render_question:
A 63-year-old man comes to the physician because of shortness of breath and swollen extremities for 2 weeks. He has had excessive night sweats and a 4-kg (8.8-lb) weight loss over the last 4 weeks. He had an anterior myocardial infarction 3 years ago. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. He immigrated from Taiwan 3 months ago. He works in a shipyard. His older brother has hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 48 years. He does not drink alcohol. Current medications include insulin, aspirin, simvastatin, metoprolol, and ramipril. He is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 46.7 kg (103 lb); BMI is 18.2 kg/m2. His temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/95 mm Hg. Examination shows generalized pitting edema. There is jugular vein distention, hepatomegaly, and a paradoxical increase in jugular venous pressure on inspiration. Chest x-ray shows bilateral pleural effusion, patchy infiltrates in the right middle lobe, and pericardial thickening and calcifications. Laboratory studies show:















 Serum Urea nitrogen 25 mg/dL Creatinine  1.5 mg/dL Urine Blood negative Glucose negative Protein 1+ 
 Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient’s symptoms?
questions.render_hint: Generalized pitting edema, jugular venous distention, paradoxical increase in jugular venous pressure on inspiration (Kussmaul's sign), and pericardial calcifications are all suggestive of constrictive pericarditis. What is the most likely etiology in this recently immigrated patient with night sweats and weight loss?

a.walk_why: Uremia is the excess of urea nitrogen in the blood, typically caused by chronic kidney disease. Severe uremia may affect the heart, causing fibrinous pericarditis. This patient has pericarditis; however, this patient’s urea nitrogen is only marginally elevated, making uremia as the explanation for this patient’s symptoms unlikely.

b.walk_why: Myocarditis is inflammation of the heart muscle most commonly caused by viruses. Acute viral myocarditis is typically a sequela of a viral upper respiratory infection and may lead to concurrent inflammation of the pericardium. Although this patient’s shortness of breath and fever may point to myocarditis, this patient does not have any chest pain or cardiac arrhythmias, which are typical findings in myocarditis. Additionally, pericardial thickening and calcifications suggest chronic pericarditis.

c.walk_why: Asbestosis is a chronic lung disease that results from exposure to asbestos fibers. Although this patient’s occupation as a shipyard worker may suggest possible exposure to asbestos fibers, the absence of cough and interstitial fibrosis on imaging make this diagnosis unlikely.

d.walk_why: Amyloidosis is characterized by the build-up of abnormal protein fibers in various tissues. In the heart, amyloidosis causes restrictive cardiomyopathy, presenting with signs of diastolic heart failure. This patient, however, has a paradoxical increase in jugular venous pressure on inspiration, which is a sign of systolic heart failure. The findings of dyspnea, jugular venous distention, and hepatomegaly may suggest heart failure, but amyloidosis would not explain the night sweats and the pericardial thickening.

e.walk_why: Type 2 diabetes mellitus is a chronic disease affecting the metabolism of glucose. Complications of diabetes mellitus include diabetic nephropathy, which may present with peripheral and pulmonary edema in cases of nephrotic-range proteinuria. However, the laboratory values only suggest mild kidney damage, and diabetes mellitus would not explain the findings of jugular venous distention and the positive Kussmaul’s sign.

f.walk_why: Postmyocardial infarction syndrome, also known as Dressler’s syndrome, is an immune-mediated inflammation of the pericardium that usually occurs 1–8 weeks after myocardial infarction. Although this patient presents with pericarditis, the occurrence of it 3 years after this patient’s myocardial infarction would be very unusual. While this diabetic patient may have recently experienced a second, asymptomatic (“silent”) myocardial infarction, pericardial calcifications and patchy infiltrations in a lung make another underlying etiology more likely.

g.walk_why: Tuberculosis is an infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. In a patient who recently immigrated from Taiwan, the symptoms of shortness of breath and night sweats and the findings of low-grade fever and patchy infiltrations in the right lung are highly suspicious for tuberculosis. Tuberculosis may affect any organ, including the heart, and is the most common cause of constrictive pericarditis in developing countries.

questions.subject: Infectiology and hygiene
questions.render_question: A 32-year-old man with psoriasis comes to the emergency department because of nausea and vomiting for the past 2 hours. The patient has neither diarrhea nor fever. Four hours ago he ate some leftover Indian food he had ordered the night before. There is no history of serious illness. He immigrated from India 8 years ago with his family and now works as a butcher. He appears ill. His temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 115/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.render_hint: Rapid onset of vomiting following the ingestion of Indian food (presumably containing rice) is a typical scenario seen in infection with the underlying organism.

a.walk_why: Shigella dysenteriae enters the gastrointestinal tract, leading to inflammation, mucosal damage, and bloody diarrhea. It has an incubation period of 1–3 days. This patient does not have bloody diarrhea and he developed the symptoms only 2 hours following food ingestion. These findings suggest a different organism.

b.walk_why: Yersinia enterocolitica causes inflammatory diarrhea (may be bloody in severe cases), typically after ingesting contaminated milk or pork. The pathogen may also cause vomiting and abdominal tenderness in the right lower quadrant, which may mimic appendicitis (“pseudoappendicitis”). The incubation period is a couple of days. This patient developed nausea and vomiting 2 hours following the ingestion of contaminated food. Therefore, an infection with Y. enterocolitica is unlikely.

c.walk_why: Vibrio parahaemolyticus can cause foodborne illness, but typically becomes symptomatic 16–72 hours after ingestion of undercooked seafood. It is the most common cause of diarrhea in Japan. Treatment is usually supportive, but administering doxycycline or fluoroquinolones may be considered in severe cases.

d.walk_why: Staphylococcus aureus (a gram-positive bacterium) is a common cause of food poisoning. Ingestion of preformed toxins (produced by S. aureus) in contaminated food (e.g., canned meats, mayonnaise) typically causes a rapid onset of illness (1–3 hours after ingestion) with nausea and vomiting. The vignette does not mention food containing mayonnaise or canned meats and the patient started to have symptoms 2 hours after eating the lndian food. Considered together, these features suggest a different diagnosis.
d.walk_but: Food poisoning due to ingestion of preformed S. aureus toxins is one of the most important differential diagnoses, especially because of the rapid onset of symptoms and the similarity in clinical features.

e.walk_why: Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC) produces heat-labile as well as heat-stable enterotoxins, which cause diffuse watery diarrhea associated with abdominal cramping, nausea, and possibly vomiting. ETEC has an incubation period of 9 hours to 3 days and is the most common cause of traveler’s diarrhea. The vignette does not mention a recent travel history and the incubation period indicated is not fitting, meaning that an ETEC infection is unlikely.

f.walk_why: The hallmarks of an infection with Salmonella enteritidis infection are high-grade fever, severe vomiting, and inflammatory (watery-bloody) diarrhea. Salmonella are typically transmitted via the ingestion of contaminated food (poultry, poorly pasteurized eggs, and milk). The incubation period is 6–48 hours, and is largely dependent on the bacterial load in the contaminated food.

g.walk_why: Enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli (EHEC) produces verotoxin/Shiga-like toxin that causes bloody diarrhea (known as “enterohemorrhagic colitis”) and potentially nausea and vomiting. It can affect healthy adults (typically leading to an asymptomatic infection), but mainly affects newborns and the elderly. Transmission also occurs via the ingestion of contaminated food (e.g., raw beef and vegetables, milk), but the incubation period is longer (2–10 days). If toxins become systemic, hemolytic uremic syndrome may result.

h.walk_why: Campylobacter jejuni is the most common cause of bacterial diarrhea in the USA. It commonly affects children and may lead to bloody diarrhea. It is typically transmitted by the ingestion of contaminated food or via direct contact with infected animals (e.g., puppies). However, the incubation period is a couple of days and the patient does not report having diarrhea, making infection with C. jejuni unlikely.

i.walk_why: Entamoeba histolytica can cause intestinal amebiasis, which is characterized by loose stools containing mucus and bright red blood, painful defecation, abdominal pain, cramps, anorexia/weight loss, and fever. It has an incubation period of 1–4 weeks. The patient does not have diarrhea and the incubation period of his infection was 2 hours, making amebiasis unlikely.

j.walk_why: Bacillus cereus is a heat-stable, spore-forming pathogen. It grows in heated food that cools down too slowly or in food that is improperly refrigerated. Reheated rice is a common source of infection. B. cereus produces enterotoxin I (emetic form), which leads to nausea and vomiting approx. 30 minutes to 6 hours after ingestion. The patient ate some leftover Indian food (presumably containing rice) and started to have symptoms 2 hours later. Therefore, infection with B. cereus is the most likely diagnosis.
j.walk_but: Bacillus cereus also produces enterotoxin II (diarrheal form), which leads to watery diarrhea approx. 6–15 hours after ingestion. Symptoms last for approx. 24–48 hours. Treatment is supportive.

questions.subject: Infectiology and hygiene
questions.render_question: A 26-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because he has had abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting for the past 2 hours. He ate a sandwich and coleslaw from a deli about 1 hour before the symptoms began. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. His temperature is 99.6°F (37.6°C), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 122/68 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. Abdominal examination shows diffuse mild tenderness with no rigidity, rebound, or guarding. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.render_hint: Rapid onset of vomiting following the ingestion of coleslaw (presumably containing mayonnaise) is a typical scenario seen in infection with the underlying organism.

a.walk_why: Bacillus cereus is a heat-stable, spore-forming pathogen. It grows in heated food that cools down too slowly or in food that is improperly refrigerated. Reheated rice is a common source of infection. B. cereus produces enterotoxin I (emetic form), which leads to nausea and vomiting approx. 30 minutes to 6 hours after ingestion. The time frame and the symptoms of a potential B. cereus infection would match the vignette. However, the patient ate coleslaw, which is neither heated nor cooked and therefore an infection with another pathogen is more likely.

b.walk_why: Shigella dysenteriae enters the gastrointestinal tract, leading to inflammation, mucosal damage, and bloody diarrhea. It has an incubation period of 1–3 days. This patient does not have bloody diarrhea and he developed the symptoms only one hour following food ingestion. These findings suggest a different organism.

c.walk_why: The hallmarks of an infection with Salmonella enteritidis infection are high-grade fever, severe vomiting, and inflammatory (watery-bloody) diarrhea. Salmonella are typically transmitted via the ingestion of contaminated food (poultry, poorly pasteurized eggs, and milk). The incubation period is 6–48 hours, and is largely dependent on the bacterial load in the contaminated food.

d.walk_why: Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC) produces heat-labile as well as heat-stable enterotoxins, which cause diffuse watery diarrhea associated with abdominal cramping, nausea, and possibly vomiting.. ETEC has an incubation period of 9 hours to 3 days and is the most common cause of traveler’s diarrhea. The vignette does not mention a recent travel history and the incubation period indicated is not fitting, meaning that an ETEC infection is unlikely.

e.walk_why: Vibrio parahaemolyticus can also cause foodborne illness, but typically 16–72 hours after ingestion of undercooked seafood. It is the most common cause of diarrhea in Japan. Treatment is usually supportive, but doxycycline or fluoroquinolones may be administered in severe cases.

f.walk_why: Campylobacter jejuni is the most common cause of bacterial diarrhea in the USA. It commonly affects children and may lead to bloody diarrhea. It is typically transmitted by the ingestion of contaminated food or via direct contact with infected animals (e.g., puppies). However, the incubation period is a couple of days and the patient does not report having diarrhea, making infection with C. jejuni unlikely.

g.walk_why: Entamoeba histolytica can cause intestinal amebiasis, which is characterized by loose stools containing mucus and bright red blood, painful defecation, abdominal pain, cramps, anorexia/weight loss, and fever. It has an incubation period of 1–4 weeks. The patient does not have diarrhea and the incubation period of his infection was about one hour, making amebiasis unlikely.

h.walk_why: Yersinia enterocolitica causes inflammatory diarrhea (may be bloody in severe cases), typically after ingesting contaminated milk or pork. The pathogen may also cause vomiting and abdominal tenderness in the right lower quadrant, which may mimic appendicitis (“pseudoappendicitis”). The incubation period is a couple of days. This patient developed nausea and vomiting one hour following the ingestion of contaminated food. Therefore, an infection with Y. enterocolitica is unlikely.

i.walk_why: Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) produces verotoxin/Shiga-like toxin that causes bloody diarrhea (known as “enterohemorrhagic colitis”) and potentially nausea and vomiting. It can affect healthy adults (typically leading to an asymptomatic infection), but mainly affects newborns and the elderly. Transmission also occurs via the ingestion of contaminated food (e.g., raw beef and vegetables, milk), but the incubation period is longer (2–10 days). If toxins become systemic, hemolytic uremic syndrome may result.

j.walk_why: This patient has an infection with Staphylococcus aureus (a gram-positive bacterium), which is a common cause of food poisoning. Ingestion of preformed toxins (produced by S. aureus) in contaminated food (e.g., canned meats, mayonnaise) typically causes a rapid onset of illness (1–3 hours after ingestion) with nausea and vomiting. Resolution of symptoms normally occurs within 24–48 hours. Antibiotics are unnecessary.

questions.subject: Gastroenterology
questions.render_question: A 56-year-old woman comes to the physician beacuse of a 6-month history of difficulty swallowing food. Initially, only solid food was problematic, but over the last 2 months she has noted that liquids are also becoming difficult to swallow. She also reports occasional regurgitation of food when she lies down. She is an avid birdwatcher and returned from a 3-week trip to the Amazon rainforest 3 months ago. She has had a 3.5-kg (7.7-lb) weight loss over the past 6 months. She has not had abdominal pain, blood in her stools, or fever. She underwent an abdominal hysterectomy for fibroid uterus 6 years ago. She has a 4-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus. Her brother is currently being treated for lung cancer. She has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. Current medications include metformin and sitagliptin. The examination shows no abnormalities. Her hemoglobin concentration is 12.2 g/dL and her fasting blood glucose is 178 mg/dL. Esophageal manometry monitoring shows the lower esophageal sphincter fails to relax during swallowing. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.render_hint: Dysphagia to solids and liquids, along with the manometry findings (impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter), are indicative of achalasia. However, it is important to rule out differential diagnoses considering her weight loss and history of smoking.

a.walk_why: Myotomy is the longitudinal incision of the lower esophageal sphincter. It is usually combined with a fundoplication to prevent gastroesophageal reflux. Although this is one of the first-line treatments for patients with achalasia, potential causes of pseudoachalasia should be evaluated before definitive treatment can be considered.

b.walk_why: Gastroesophageal endoscopy, the inspection of the esophagus and the stomach with an endoscope, is indicated in this patient to rule out esophageal cancer as a cause of achalasia (referred to as pseudoachalasia). Esophageal cancer and achalasia can present similarly, which is why it is important to maintain a high index of suspicion for esophageal cancer. In this particular patient, significant weight loss and a history of smoking are findings that would support the diagnosis of esophageal cancer, making endoscopic inspection necessary.
b.walk_but: Achalasia can also be a cause of esophageal cancer, although cancer is unlikely to arise within a period of just 6 months.

c.walk_why: Giemsa staining of a blood smear may be used to evaluate for various bacterial and protozoal infections, including infection with Trypanosoma cruzi, the pathogen that causes Chagas disease. Chagas disease may present with megaesophagus and achalasia. Although this patient recently traveled to the Amazon rainforest, an area where Chagas disease is endemic, achalasia is usually a sequela that appears in the chronic phase of Chagas disease, 10–20 years after primary infection. Furthermore, the patient’s symptoms started prior to her trip to the rainforest. Finally, we would expect a patient with Chagas disease to present with other symptoms, such as fever, generalized lymphadenopathy, arrythmias, or constipation.

d.walk_why: Nifedipine is a calcium channel blocker that may be considered as a symptomatic treatment for achalasia in patients with a high surgical risk who have not received adequate relief from botulinum toxin injections. This patient has not undergone any prior treatment for achalasia. Therefore, nifedipine would not be the preferred choice in this patient at this time.

e.walk_why: Barium swallow, or barium esophagram, is a contrast-enhanced imaging technique for the esophagus that may be used for assessing many esophageal conditions. If achalasia is present, barium swallow typically shows a “bird-beak appearance” of the gastroesophageal junction and delayed emptying of the esophagus. However, esophageal manometry, the test of choice, has already indicated achalasia. Barium swallow would therefore not yield any additional diagnostic clues regarding achalasia. It is also not the most sensitive nor the most specific method for ruling out other diseases that may present similarly to achalasia.

f.walk_why: Botulinum toxin is a drug that inhibits the release of stimulatory neurotransmitters at the neuromuscular junction, causing muscle paralysis. Injections of botulinum toxin into the lower esophageal sphincter may be used to treat achalasia, primarily in patients who are poor surgical candidates. In this patient, pneumatic dilation or lower esophageal sphincter myotomy would be attempted first.

questions.subject: Infectiology and hygiene
questions.render_question: A 58-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of dysphagia and swelling in the neck and lower jaw. He has had tooth pain on the left side over the past week, which has made it difficult for him to sleep. Four weeks ago, he had a 3-day episode of flu-like symptoms, including sore throat, that resolved without treatment. He has a history of hypertension. Current medications include metformin and lisinopril. He appears distressed. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lbs); his BMI is 31.6 kg/m2. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg. Oral cavity examination shows a decayed lower left third molar with drainage of pus. There is submandibular and anterior neck tenderness and swelling. His leukocyte count is 15,600/mm3, platelet count is 300,000/mm3, and fingerstick blood glucose concentration is 250 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.render_hint: An odontogenic infection and swollen, tender neck in a diabetic patient likely indicates spread of the infection towards the soft tissue of the neck.

a.walk_why: Peritonsillar abscess is an abscess that forms in the area between the palatine tonsil and its capsule that presents with unilateral sore throat, odynophagia, tender lymphadenopathy, and possible trismus. If the abscess progresses, it can involve the surrounding muscles or, rarely, the carotid sheath. It most commonly occurs as a complication of recurrent tonsillitis. Although the patient did have a sore throat 4 weeks ago, peritonsillar abscess is a more acute illness. Additionally, peritonsillar abscess is not associated with an odontogenic infection as is seen in this patient. Furthermore, in peritonsillar abscess, examination of the oral cavity would show a collection of pus in the peritonsillar area and possible uvula deviation, which are not described in this patient.

b.walk_why: Ludwig’s angina is a rare and often fatal soft-tissue infection (a form of cellulitis) of the neck and floor of the mouth, which is known for aggressively progressing and compromising the airways. The condition is often caused by odontogenic infection, and diabetes is a predisposing factor. The patient has a molar infection along with fever, dysphagia, and swelling of the submandibular and anterior portion of the neck, which suggests the infection has spread from the molar towards the submandibular and sublingual space. Therefore, Ludwig’s angina is the most likely diagnosis. If not treated promptly with IV antibiotics, airway control, and surgical drainage, it can be fatal.

c.walk_why: Sublingual hematoma is bleeding and swelling that occurs under the tongue, especially after oral or dental surgery. It is especially common in people with bleeding disorders or those undergoing anticoagulant therapy. The oral examination of the patient shows only an odontogenic infection, and he does not have any of the risk factors listed above for a sublingual hematoma. In addition, the fever and the raised WBC count would make this diagnosis unlikely.

d.walk_why: Lymphadenitis is the inflammation of a lymph node that causes it to become tender and enlarged. It is a common immune response to fighting infections and sometimes neoplasms. The patient did have a sore throat 4 weeks ago, but any associated lymphadenitis should have already subsided. While the odontogenic infection may predispose to lymphadenitis, the dysphagia and swelling of the anterior neck cannot be explained solely on the basis of this diagnosis.

e.walk_why: Angioedema is an acute swelling of the deep dermal layers of the skin, predominantly around the eyes, lips, and tongue that occurs acutely. When severe, it can cause laryngeal edema and lead to respiratory distress. It may be allergic or hereditary. The patient is currently taking lisinopril – a drug known to cause angioedema – and presents with swelling and dysphagia. However, his eyes, lips, and tongue would also be affected. Additionally, the fever, infected molar, and tenderness would not be expected.

questions.subject: Neurology
questions.render_question: A 37-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife after having a seizure. He has a 1-week history of headaches, blurry vision in his right eye, and muscle pain in his arms and neck, for which he has been taking ibuprofen. There is no history of a seizure disorder and his vision has been normal until the onset of his symptoms 1 week ago. He has a history of migraine headaches that occur on a monthly basis and are relieved with NSAIDs. He immigrated from Mexico 6 years ago and returns often to visit his family. He appears confused. His vital signs are within normal limits. Ophthalmologic examination shows subretinal cysts. An MRI of the brain shows multiple small, ring-enhancing lesions in the parenchyma. A lumbar puncture is done; cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows numerous eosinophils and a protein concentration of 53 mg/dL. Immunotransfer blot confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most likely cause of infection in this patient?
questions.render_hint: This patient has a first presentation of seizure and a history of headache with blurry vision and myalgia. Given the examination findings of subretinal cysts, ring-enhancing lesions on MRI, and the eosinophils in CSF, he most likely has neurocysticercosis.

a.answer: Ingestion of larva from raw pork
a.walk_why: Trichinella spiralis may be transmitted by the ingestion of larvae in undercooked pork meat, causing trichinellosis. After the ingestion of contaminated meat, the larvae disseminate through the bloodstream and enter skeletal muscle and sometimes other tissue such as cardiac muscle and the central nervous system. Although this disorder may present with myalgias and neurological manifestations, it seldom causes seizures. Additionally, it presents with fever and periorbital edema, features that are absent in this patient.

b.walk_why: Ingestion of undercooked fish is the mode of transmission of Diphyllobothrium latum (fish tapeworm), which causes diphyllobothriasis. Although the incidence of this infection in the US has declined, some outbreaks associated with ingestion of fresh salmon have been reported. Most of the patients with this condition do not have clinical manifestations, but some may develop megaloblastic anemia as a result of the tapeworm ingesting vitamin B12 (however, neurological symptoms generally do not occur). Diphyllobothriasis does not cause seizures, myalgias, headaches, or blurry vision.

c.walk_why: Inhalation of airborne spores is the route of infection for several fungi, including Aspergillus spp. and Cryptococcus neoformans. In patients with an impaired immune systems (e.g., HIV, immunosuppression after organ transplant), these fungi can cause invasive disease, presenting with ring-enhancing brain lesions. However, the patient history does not indicate immunocompromise, making another diagnosis more likely.
c.walk_but: Imaging may show ring-enhancing lesions for cases in which C. neoformans infects the brain.

d.answer: Ingestion of eggs from cat feces
d.walk_why: Ingestion of contaminated cat feces is a mode of transmission for toxocariasis and toxoplasmosis. Toxocariasis (caused by eggs of Toxocara cati, a roundworm) and toxoplasmosis (caused by cysts of Toxoplasma gondii, an intracellular protozoan) are usually asymptomatic. In rare cases, toxocariasis can affect the CNS, causing seizures and visual impairment. It may also present with ring-enhancing lesions on MRI. However, CNS involvement in toxocariasis is a rare event, and the disease does not present with subretinal cysts. In patients with severe immunosuppression (e.g., HIV), toxoplasmosis can also cause illness with ring-enhancing lesions on MRI. However, this patient is not immunosuppressed and does not have any risk factors for an HIV infection (e.g., intravenous drug abuse, unprotected sex).

e.answer: Ingestion of eggs from dog feces
e.walk_why: Toxocara canis (dog roundworm) and Echinococcus granulosus (hydatid tapeworm) are two parasites that can be acquired by ingestion of eggs from the feces of an infected dog. Symptoms of toxocariasis include fever, anorexia, dyspnea, and visual impairment (ocular larva migrans). However, toxocariasis does not cause seizures nor has ring-enhancing lesions on a MRI, which makes another diagnosis more likely. Echinococcosis is classically a condition of the liver and lungs, and may present with nausea, cough, chest pain, and dyspnea, symptoms that this patient lacks.
e.walk_but: E. granulosis form cysts that may be located in the brain and cause seizures, although this is rare and would typically also involve other organs (e.g., liver).

f.answer: Ingestion of larval cysts from raw beef
f.walk_why: Taenia saginata (beef tapeworm) may be transmitted by ingesting larval cysts (cysticerci) in undercooked beef meat. After ingestion of cysticerci, the parasite matures in the gastrointestinal tract and the adult worm may survive in the small intestine for several years. Patients with taeniasis are usually asymptomatic but may present with gastrointestinal discomfort. However, taeniasis does not affect other organs.

g.answer: Ingestion of eggs from human feces
g.walk_why: Based on his history and symptoms, this patient most likely has neurocysticercosis. Individuals can acquire this disease by ingesting Taenia solium (a tapeworm) eggs present in the feces of a human carrier. The eggs hatch in the intestines and eventually release larval cysts (cysticerci) in the body, which disseminate to the muscles and central nervous system. The immune response elicited by the cysticerci is responsible for neurological manifestations like those observed in this patient. Most cases of neurocysticercosis in the US are immigrants from Latin American countries such as Mexico.
g.walk_but: In neurocysticercosis, humans are an incidental dead-end host for Taenia solium because the parasite is unable to complete its life cycle. It should not be confused with intestinal taeniasis, which occurs after ingestion of contaminated raw pork meat and does not lead to neurological symptoms.

h.answer: Ingestion of eggs after scratching anal region
h.walk_why: Enterobiasis, caused by Enterobius vermicularis (pinworm), is the most common helminthic infection in the US. Primary infection is acquired by fecal-oral transmission, but individuals become reinfected after scratching the anal region, where this parasite deposits eggs (autoinoculation). The disease usually presents with anal pruritus; neurological symptoms, such as headaches and seizures, do not occur.

questions.subject: Infectiology and hygiene
questions.render_question:
A 56-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of high-grade fever and chills for 5 days. She also reports worsening pain and swelling in her right knee for 3 days. She has not had shortness of breath, chest pain, or headache. She underwent a total knee arthroplasty of her right knee joint 5 months ago. The procedure and immediate aftermath were uneventful. She has hypertension and osteoarthritis. Current medications include glucosamine, amlodipine, and meloxicam. Her temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Examination shows a tender swollen right knee joint; range of motion is limited. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Arthrocentesis of the right knee is performed. Analysis of joint fluid aspirate shows:











 Appearance  Purulent Viscosity Absent WBC count 78,000/mm3
 Segmented neutrophils 94% Lymphocytes 6% 
 The joint aspirate is sent for culture and antibiotic sensitivity. Urinalysis is within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely to grow in the joint aspirate culture?
questions.render_hint: This patient's presentation with a tender and swollen knee, high-grade fevers, tachycardia, and hypotension is suggestive of severe infectious arthritis. Her history of recent arthroplasty as well as the finding of purulent synovial fluid with an increased WBC count make a bacterial prosthetic joint infection most likely.

a.walk_why: Staphylococcus epidermidis is a gram-positive bacteria that has the ability to form a biofilm. It can therefore grow on the surface of foreign material such as prosthetic joints, prosthetic cardiac valves, IV catheters, and pacemakers. The patient underwent an arthroplasty in her right knee 5 months ago and is now presenting with septic arthritis, which makes a foreign body infection very likely. S. epidermidis is the most common cause of prosthetic infections 3–12 month after surgery.
a.walk_but: Treatment of prosthetic joint infections usually consists of removal of the prosthesis and debridement of the bone and surrounding tissue, followed by IV antibiotics (e.g., oxacillin or ceftriaxone) for 6–8 weeks. Reimplantation of the prosthesis should be performed after repeat negative synovial fluid cultures or after completion of antimicrobial therapy if clinical signs of infection are absent.

b.walk_why: Streptococcus agalactiae (or group B Streptococcus) is a gram-positive bacteria that most commonly causes septicemia, pneumonia, and meningitis in newborn children. It does not commonly cause septic arthritis, making this choice unlikely.

c.walk_why: Staphylococcus aureus is a gram-positive bacteria that commonly causes skin and soft-tissue infections. It is the most common cause of septic arthritis. However, given the fact that the patient has a prosthetic implant in the affected knee and presents 5 months after surgery, an infection with a different pathogen is more likely.
c.walk_but: If the patient had presented within < 3 months after the arthroplasty or > 12 months after surgery, this option would be most likely.

d.walk_why: Escherichia coli is a gram-negative rod that is part of the normal intestinal flora but can cause a variety of infections, such as urinary tract infections and nosocomial infections. It can also cause septic arthritis in immunosuppressed patients, however the patient has no history of immunosuppression, making this answer unlikely.

e.walk_why: Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative rod that most commonly causes nosocomial infections and is found in immunosuppressed patients with arthritis. The patient has no history of conditions that would predispose her to P. aeruginosa infection (e.g., underlying malignancy, IV drug use, diabetes mellitus), which makes this choice unlikely.

questions.subject: Infectiology and hygiene
questions.render_question:
A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with dry cough, shortness of breath, and low-grade fever that began 6 days ago. He also reports that he has had three episodes of watery diarrhea per day for the last two days. He has a history of hypertension that is treated with hydrochlorothiazide. He does not smoke and occasionally drinks a glass of wine. He appears slightly pale and in mild distress. His temperature is 39.2°C (102.5°F), pulse is 65/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 140/78 mm Hg. Diffuse crackles are heard in the thorax. A grade 2/6 systolic murmur is heard best at the left sternal border and second intercostal space. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:





















 Hemoglobin  13.8 g/dL Leukocyte count 16,000/mm3
 Platelet count  150,000/mm3
 Serum Na+ 131 mEq/L Cl-
102 mEq/L K+
  4.7 mEq/L HCO3-
 26 mEq/L Urea Nitrogen 18 g/dL Creatinine  1.2 g/dL 
 An x-ray of the chest shows patchy infiltrates in both lungs. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.render_hint: The patient has watery diarrhea in combination with signs of atypical pneumonia, including dyspnea, dry cough, and low-grade fever. These features together with hyponatremia and an X-ray with bilateral patchy infiltrates suggest infection with Legionella pneumophila, which is treated by a drug that inhibits DNA gyrase.

a.walk_why: Trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole (TMP/SMX) is a combination medication in which both components inhibit different steps of the bacterial folate synthesis pathway. It may be administered in case of legionellosis, but only as a alternative to failed or contraindicated first-line therapy. TMP/SMX is also used to treat a variety of other diseases (e.g., Pneumocystis pneumonia, toxoplasmosis, and urinary tract infections). Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP) also presents with diffuse bilateral interstitial infiltrates on chest x-ray, which may mimic legionellosis. However, PCP affects immunocompromised patients and it does not present with watery diarrhea or decreased serum sodium.

b.walk_why: Amoxicillin, a beta-lactam antibiotic, is effective against Gram-positive and some Gram-negative infections. It is also the drug of choice for treating community-acquired lobar pneumonia. The patient presents with dry cough, shortness of breath, and low-grade fever, which may mimic community-acquired lobar pneumonia. However, a chest x-ray of lobar pneumonia is typically notable for an extensive opacity that is restricted to one pulmonary lobe and this patient’s x-ray shows bilateral patchy infiltrates. These findings, together with watery diarrhea, decreased serum sodium, and a positive urinary antigen test make the diagnosis of lobar pneumonia unlikely.

c.walk_why: Levofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone and is the treatment of choice for legionellosis, which is caused by Legionella pneumophila. It has excellent activity against most strains of bacterial pathogens responsible for gastrointestinal, respiratory, and urinary tract infections, including gram-negative, gram-positive, and atypical bacteria. Fluoroquinolones inhibit topoisomerase enzymes, preventing bacterial DNA from winding and unwinding. Acceptable second-line treatments for legionellosis include macrolides such as azithromycin. Legionellosis has two clinical manifestations: Pontiac fever and Legionnaires’ disease. Pontiac fever is a mild flulike condition that is self-limiting. Legionnaires’ disease presents with atypical pneumonia and diarrhea, which is consistent with this patient’s findings. Legionellosis is confirmed via a positive urine antigen test.
c.walk_but: Formerly, intravenously administered macrolides were the drug of choice. However, recent studies have shown significantly more rapid relief of symptoms and a lower complication rate with fluoroquinolone therapy.

d.walk_why: Rifampin, an RNA polymerase inhibitor, used to be one of the treatment options in patients with legionellosis, but only in combination with fluoroquinolones or macrolides. However, combination therapy is only administered as a second-line therapy in patients who do not respond to monotherapy with fluoroquinolone. Furthermore, there have been conflicting studies regarding the benefits of combination therapy with Rifampin. However, rifampin is first-line therapy for tuberculosis and leprosy. Although patients with tuberculosis present with dry cough, dyspnea, and low-grade fever, this patient’s hyponatremia, diarrhea, and X-ray findings would not be expected in tuberculosis.

e.walk_why: Oseltamivir, an antiviral, blocks neuraminidase, inhibiting the release of viral particles. It is used to treat influenza A and B. The patient presents with dry cough, shortness of breath, and a low-grade fever which may mimic an influenza infection. However, influenza does not typically produce watery diarrhea in adults and is not detectable with urinary antigen testing. Additionally, decreased serum sodium and bilateral patchy infiltrates on chest x-ray are not typical for influenza. If the patient actually had influenza, oseltamivir would only help if administered within 48 hours of symptom onset.

questions.subject: OB/Gyn
questions.render_question: An 18-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with 5-day history of severe abdominal pain, cramping, nausea, and vomiting. She also has pain with urination. She is sexually active with one male partner, and they use condoms inconsistently. She experienced a burning pain when she last had sexual intercourse 3 days ago. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals and last 5 days. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 83/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows abdominal tenderness in the lower quadrants. Pelvic examination shows cervical motion tenderness and purulent cervical discharge. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 15,000/mm3 and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 100 mm/h. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.render_hint: Cervical motion tenderness and purulent cervical discharge in a young, sexually active woman should point you toward the correct diagnosis.

a.walk_why: Cystitis is an infection of the bladder that is most commonly caused by ascending infection with bacteria such as Escherichia coli. This patient presents with dysuria and lower abdominal pain, both of which are symptoms of cystitis. However, she also has a fever, which is uncommon in cases of cystitis. In addition, cystitis does not classically present with cervical motion tenderness or vaginal discharge, though gross hematuria may be present. Lastly, while the pain of cystitis tends to be localized suprapubically, this patient has pain in both lower abdominal quadrants.

b.walk_why: Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) is an ascending bacterial infection of the upper female reproductive tract. The classic presentation consists of lower abdominal pain (generally bilateral), cervical motion tenderness, and purulent vaginal discharge in a young, sexually active patient, as presented by this young woman. Other associated clinical features include dyspareunia and dysuria, which are also present here. Laboratory studies showing leukocytosis and an elevated ESR are also consistent with PID. All cases of PID require antibiotic treatment particularly because it can cause permanent damage to the fallopian tubes, even resulting in infertility. As it is a polymicrobial disease, treatment usually includes broad-spectrum antibiotics such as third-generation cephalosporins.

c.walk_why: Nephrolithiasis refers to the formation of renal calculi, or kidney stones. It typically presents with unilateral, colicky flank pain. The pain may radiate to the lower abdomen and the groin. This patient does present with lower abdominal pain, but she also displays a variety of additional symptoms not found in patients with kidney stones (e.g., cervical motion tenderness, purulent vaginal discharge, dyspareunia).

d.walk_why: An ovarian cyst is a fluid-filled sac located in the ovary and is a product of follicular development and maturation. An ovarian cyst rupture causes sudden, unilateral lower abdominal pain and typically occurs during periods of physical activity (e.g., exercise, sexual intercourse). This patient’s pain is bilateral and although she reports dyspareunia during sexual intercourse 3 days ago, her symptoms began 2 days prior to that. Moreover, the pain of a ruptured ovarian cyst is usually not associated with signs of infection such as fever or purulent discharge (as seen in this patient).

e.walk_why: Ectopic pregnancy is a pregnancy occurring outside of the uterus, most commonly in the fallopian tubes. One of the most important findings in ectopic pregnancy is vaginal bleeding, which is absent in this patient. Additionally, symptoms usually appear 4–6 weeks after the last normal menstrual period, whereas this patient’s last period was just 3 weeks ago. Cervical motion tenderness, uterine tenderness, or adnexal tenderness may be present in ectopic pregnancy, but the purulent cervical discharge seen on examination of this patient is not a characteristic finding.
e.walk_but: Abdominal pain is a common finding in ectopic pregnancy. Nausea and vomiting (together with other normal signs of pregnancy such as breast tenderness or urinary frequency) may also occur. Definitive diagnosis would be made by urine pregnancy test and ultrasound.

f.walk_why: Vulvovaginitis is an inflammation of the vulva and vagina. This patient’s lower abdominal pain, purulent discharge, dyspareunia, and dysuria are all characteristic of vulvovaginitis. However, the pelvic exam shows cervical motion tenderness, which is characteristic of inflammation of the upper reproductive tract rather than the vulva or vagina. She also has symptoms that are generally more severe than those caused by vulvovaginitis (e.g., severe pain, fever).
f.walk_but: The vaginal discharge in vulvovaginitis is important for differential diagnosis. Purulent discharge is seen in Chlamydia or Gonorrhea infections. Greyish discharge with a fishy odor indicates bacterial vaginosis (Gardnerella vaginalis). Frothy, yellow-green, and foul-smelling discharge is caused by Trichomonas vaginalis. White, crumbly discharge is seen in vaginal yeast infections.

g.walk_why: Appendicitis is an acute inflammation of the appendix. Important findings in appendicitis include fever, abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting, which are present in this patient. Her lab findings are also typical of appendicitis (e.g., elevated leukocyte count and ESR) and other conditions of inflammation or infection. However, classically the pain of appendicitis is initially periumbilical and later migrates to the right lower quadrant, whereas this patient is experiencing pain bilaterally in the lower abdomen. In addition, purulent cervical discharge and cervical motion tenderness indicate infection of the reproductive organs rather than the appendix.

questions.subject: Infectiology and hygiene
questions.render_question: A 70-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of back pain. For the past six days, she has had a burning pain in her upper right back and chest. She cannot recall any recent injury and has no prior history of back pain. She has a history of hypertension and gastroesophageal reflux. The patient volunteers at an animal shelter three times a week. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Current medications include ramipril and pantoprazole. The patient appears healthy and well nourished. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.42°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 145/92 mm Hg. Examination shows a long erythematous rash covered with multiple clear vesicles and crusty lesions extending from her back to below her right breast. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of the disease?
questions.render_hint: This patient has multiple vesicles and crusty lesions with severe burning pain, located in a well-circumscribed area of the body, which probably corresponds to a dermatome. These features are typical of a shingles infection.

a.answer: Viral reactivation in dorsal root ganglia
a.walk_why: Viral reactivation in dorsal root ganglia refers to a herpes virus infection. The presence of a vesicular rash on an erythematous base involving 1–3 adjacent dermatomes with intense pain and burning is suggestive of a varicella zoster infection. Typically, the pain precedes other symptoms by a couple of days and can result in severe debilitating postherpetic neuralgia once the rash has resolved.
a.walk_but: The initial infection with varicella zoster occurs as chickenpox and the virus remains dormant in dorsal root ganglia after the infection. In periods of stress or in immunocompromised and vulnerable populations like the elderly, the virus may be reactivated and result in shingles.

b.walk_why: A type IV hypersensitivity drug reaction would indicate erythema multiforme. Though ramipril can cause erythema multiforme, it is one of its rarer side effects. Erythema multiforme presents with itching as the primary symptom and occurs as pink blotches on the extremities with a blanching center, appearing as a ‘target lesion.’ It is not limited to adjacent dermatomes. The burning sensation, along with the presence of vesicles and crusting, over 1–3 adjacent dermatomes makes a type IV hypersensitivity drug reaction an unlikely mechanism of the rash.
b.walk_but: Contact dermatitis is also a Type IV hypersensitivity reaction, but there is no irritant in the history that might cause it and it tends to be more chronic.

c.answer: IgA deposits in the upper dermis
c.walk_why: IgA deposits in the upper dermis are immunofluorescence findings of dermatitis herpetiformis. Though the rash typical of dermatitis herpetiformis can have a papulovesicular appearance, it is more chronic and is not limited to adjacent dermatomes. Moreover, the vignette does not mention any history suggestive of celiac disease or gluten sensitivity, which is usually associated with dermatitis herpetiformis. Dermatitis herpetiformis commonly manifests between the ages of 15–40. Therefore, dermatitis herpetiformis and the presence of IgA deposits in the upper dermis of the skin are unlikely. The patient’s clinical features are suggestive of shingles, which has another mechanism of causing disease.

d.answer: Bacterial lymphatic infection of the epidermis
d.walk_why: Bacterial infection of the epidermis and superficial lymphatics would indicate erysipelas. Erysipelas is most commonly caused by Streptococcus pyogenes and results in a well demarcated erythematous rash along with signs of inflammation. Fever, chills, and myalgia also occur within a couple of days of the rash developing. The burning pain, vesicular rash along adjacent dermatomes, and the absence of systemic signs makes erysipelas unlikely. These clinical features are consistent with shingles, which has another mechanism of causing disease.

e.walk_why: Infestation with bloodsucking parasites in this case vignette might involve a flea infection, as this woman volunteers at an animal shelter regularly. Flea bites would result in itchy papular urticaria and would be more widespread than just the upper back and chest. The presence of vesicles in adjacent dermatomes and preceding burning pain makes a flea infestation unlikely in this woman. These clinical features are consistent with shingles, which have another mechanism of causing disease.

f.walk_why: A gram-negative bacillus potentially relevant to this vignette would be Bartonella henselae, which causes cat-scratch disease. Cat-scratch disease might be suspected in this patient because she works in an animal shelter. However, cat-scratch disease would present with a single vesicle at the scratch or bite site and commonly results in lymphadenopathy, which is not seen in this woman. The presence of multiple vesicles and crusting lesions in adjacent dermatomes make cat-scratch disease an unlikely cause of the patient’s symptoms.

g.answer: Mite burrows into the stratum corneum
g.walk_why: Mites burrowing into the stratum corneum refers to Sarcoptes scabiei infesting the superficial layer of the skin. This patient’s rash is present under the breast, which is a common site for a scabietic rash. However, scabies rarely manifests as a rash over the back. In addition, the rash caused by scabies is not painful or vesicular in appearance. These painful vesicles limited to adjacent dermatomes are indicative of shingles.

h.walk_why: Myocardial ischemia typically presents with severe retrosternal burning pain but could also result in burning pain over the upper back and chest, as seen in this woman. However, the pain has lasted for 6 days, and she has no other associated symptoms like dyspnea, diaphoresis, or hemodynamic instability that might suggest an acute myocardial event. The presence of a vesicular rash in adjacent dermatomes and the duration of the pain would therefore make myocardial ischemia an unlikely cause of the patient’s symptoms.
h.walk_but: In elderly patients with cardiac risk factors such as hypertension, myocardial ischemia must always be ruled out in those who present with burning pain over the chest and back, especially if there is no rash visible.

i.walk_why: Brown recluse spider bites commonly go unnoticed and can result in blister formation a couple of hours after the bite. In some cases, they can progress to tissue destruction and necrosis, along with systemic symptoms of fever, myalgias, and nausea. The presence of multiple vesicles along adjacent dermatomes, as well as the preceding burning sensation from the upper back to the chest, make a bite from a brown recluse spider unlikely. These clinical features are more consistent with shingles, which has another mechanism of causing disease.

questions.subject: OB/Gyn
questions.render_question: A 28-year-old woman comes to the physician because of lower abdominal pain for the past 5 days. She also reports purulent vaginal discharge. Menses occur at irregular 20 to 40-day intervals and last 4 to 8 days. She is sexually active with a new partner that she met 2 months ago und they use condoms inconsistently. She had a normal pap smear 5 months ago. She has no history of serious illness. She drinks 2 beers every other day. She occasionally smokes marijuana. Her temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 108/75 mm Hg. Examination shows lower abdominal tenderness and bilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy. Pelvic examination is notable for uterine and adnexal tenderness as well as small amounts of bloody cervical discharge. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 14,500/mm3 and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 90 mm/h. Nucleic acid amplification confirms the suspected diagnosis. The patient is started on ceftriaxone and doxycycline. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.render_hint: Based on her presentation of vaginal discharge, dysuria, and uterine tenderness, as well as the nucleic acid amplification findings likely confirming Chlamydia trachomatis infection, this patient has been diagnosed and treated for pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). PID is most commonly caused by C. trachomatis and/or Neisseria gonorrhoeae as a result of sexual activity without barrier protection, which puts her at risk for other sexually transmitted infections.

a.walk_why: Exploratory laparoscopy is a minimally invasive surgical procedure that allows diagnosis of several intra-abdominal conditions with the use of a camera. It is performed in cases in which the diagnosis is unclear (e.g., unexplained abdominal pain despite appropriate laboratory and imaging tests). This patient does not need such a procedure because the diagnosis of pelvic inflammatory disease has been established and the appropriate therapy administered.
a.walk_but: An exploratory laparoscopy may be indicated in this patient if she fails to respond to the antibiotic treatment.

b.walk_why: All patients with PID caused by Chlamydia should also receive empirical treatment (e.g., ceftriaxone) against gonococcal infection. As this patient is already receiving ceftriaxone, no further testing for N. gonorrhoeae is necessary.

c.walk_why: Colposcopy is the observation of the vagina and cervix through the use of a colposcope, a magnifying instrument. It is used as a screening method for premalignant and malignant lesions (e.g., lesions from human papillomavirus infection or cervical cancer), usually after an abnormal pap smear. It is also indicated in cases of postcoital bleeding. As this patient has already been already diagnosed with pelvic inflammatory disease, it is likely that she had a colposcopy as part of the workup. Therefore, she does not require an additional colposcopy.

d.walk_why: An abdominal CT scan is a test used for diagnosis of conditions affecting gastrointestinal organs (e.g., complicated acute appendicitis, abscesses). However, this patient was already diagnosed with pelvic inflammatory disease due to a chlamydial infection, and treatment has been started. Moreover, there is no evidence of abdominal disease at this time that would justify a CT scan.

e.walk_why: Tzanck smear is a cytodiagnostic method in which the base of a lesion (usually a blister) is scraped, smeared on a slide, and examined under a microscope. It is used to detect herpes simplex virus (HSV) 1 and 2 infections. Genital herpes infections cause dysuria and vesicles on the genitalia that may rupture and leave very tender ulcers, as well as vaginal discharge and uterine tenderness. This patient has engaged in unprotected sex, which puts her at risk for developing HSV-2 infection, but does not present with genital ulcers; therefore, testing for HSV infection is not justified.

f.walk_why: The Papanicolaou test, also known as Pap smear, is a screening test for both premalignant and malignant cervical lesions. For patients in their third decade of life, a Pap smear is routinely recommended every three years. The patient in this vignette has had a recent normal pap smear; therefore, her next pap smear should be in three years.

g.walk_why: HIV test refers to any method that allows diagnosis of human immunodeficiency virus infection, which may involve detecting antibodies against the virus or the virus itself. At earlier stages, HIV infection is often asymptomatic. Unprotected sexual intercourse is a risk factor for HIV infection. This patient has a chlamydial infection, which is also a sexually transmitted disease (STD). The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommend that all women with the diagnosis of PID should undergo HIV testing.

questions.subject: Infectiology and hygiene
questions.render_question:
A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of fatigue and myalgia. Over the past month, she has had intermittent episodes of nausea. She has a history of experimenting with intravenous illicit drugs, but she has not used illicit drugs for the past five years. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 14 years and drinks one alcoholic beverage daily. She takes no medications. Her last visit to a physician was 4 years ago.
