Her temperature is 37°C (100°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows jaundice and hepatosplenomegaly. There are also blisters and erosions on the dorsum of both hands. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:





























 Hemoglobin  12 g/dL Leukocyte count 8,300/mm³ Platelet count  250,000/mm3
 Serum Glucose 170 mg/dL Albumin 3.0 g/dL Total bilirubin 2.2 mg/dL Alkaline phosphatase  80 U/L AST 92 U/L ALT 76 U/L Hepatitis B surface antigen negative Hepatitis B surface antibody  positive Hepatitis B core antibody positive Hepatitis C antibody
  positive 
 Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
questions.render_hint: This patient has fatigue, jaundice, hepatomegaly, and a history of past intravenous drug use, which are all indicative of viral hepatitis. The positive hepatitis virus serology confirms the diagnosis. Which of these tests should be conducted to determine current viral activity?

a.walk_why: Anti-HAV IgM is the screening test for an active hepatitis A virus infection. While hepatitis A does present with jaundice, it rarely presents chronically or with splenomegaly. Though it is important to rule out other coinfections, the next step would be confirmation of the positive viral serology in the case above.

b.walk_why: Western blot is a widely used analytic technique to confirm HIV if the initial screening test is positive for HIV. Confirming an HIV infection remains an integral part of a work-up for an active intravenous drug user. However, the possibility that this patient’s symptoms are due to cirrhosis of a viral etiology makes confirmation of the viral etiology more pressing in this case above.
b.walk_but: Conducting a screening test for HIV (e.g., via ELISA) would be indicated in this patient.

c.walk_why: PCR for hepatitis C virus RNA is the confirmatory test for a chronic hepatitis C infection. The hepatitis C antibody test is a screening test and is positive in cases of active, chronic, or previous infection. The woman in the case last used IV illicit drugs 5 years ago and has been symptomatic for 3 months with clinical features of cirrhosis and portal hypertension, which suggests a chronic hepatitis C infection. Therefore, confirming the PCR for hepatitis C virus RNA would be the most appropriate next step in this patient.

d.walk_why: PCR for hepatitis B virus DNA would be conducted to confirm an active infection. However, the presence of the hepatitis B surface antibody and hepatitis B core antibody without the surface antigen being positive indicates immunity acquired through a natural infection. Therefore, there is no need to confirm a hepatitis B infection or check its viral load.

e.walk_why: While a liver biopsy is the most reliable tool for diagnosing diffuse hepatic disease, it is an invasive procedure that carries some risk. In the case presented above, the woman has clinical features that suggest cirrhosis and a possible viral etiology as well. Liver biopsy is not commonly used for diagnosis of cirrhosis of viral etiology. It is instead used for staging and evaluating the prognosis of the disease, as well as for evaluating treatment.

f.walk_why: Anti-HBc IgM are antibodies against the core hepatitis B antigen and if positive indicate an acute infection beginning in the last 6 months. However, even though the patient here has signs of active hepatic disease, the absence of the hepatitis B surface antigen and the presence of the surface antibody indicate immunity and rule out an active infection.

questions.subject: Infectiology and hygiene
questions.render_question:
A 42-year-old man comes to the physician after elevated liver function tests were found after a routine screening. He has had occasional headaches over the past year, but otherwise feels well. The patient reports that he was involved in a severe car accident 30 years ago. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. He has never used illicit intravenous drugs. He takes no medications and has no known allergies. His father had a history of alcoholism and died of liver cancer. The patient appears thin. His temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:































 Hemoglobin  14 g/dL Leukocyte count 10,000/mm³ Platelet count  146,000/mm3
 Serum Glucose 150 mg/dL Albumin 3.2 g/dL Total bilirubin 1.5 mg/dL Alkaline phosphatase  75 U/L AST 95 U/L ALT 73 U/L HIV negative Hepatitis B surface antigen negative Hepatitis C antibody  positive HCV RNA positive HCV genotype  1 
 A liver biopsy is performed and shows mononuclear infiltrates that are limited to portal tracts and periportal hepatocyte necrosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.render_hint: This patient is primarily asymptomatic, but has elevated liver function tests that require further investigation. He has both a positive hepatitis C antibody and positive HCV RNA, which together indicate an active hepatitis C infection. Furthermore, his liver biopsy supports the diagnosis of a chronic infection, meaning he should be treated with medications effective against the specific genotype, which is type 1 in this case.

a.walk_why: Tenofovir and entecavir, both nucleotide analogs, are medications that are used in the treatment of chronic hepatitis B infection. However, the laboratory studies do not include any values that correspond to a hepatitis B infection (HBsAg is negative).

b.walk_why: Interferon and ribavirin (the later is a guanosine analog) may be administered to treat patients with chronic hepatitis C infection (especially genotypes 2 and 3), nowadays typically as an alternative to direct-acting antivirals. However, this patient has an infection with hepatitis C virus genotype 1, so a combination of peginterferon alpha and ribavirin is not indicated in his case.
b.walk_but: Ribavirin may, however, be administered together with direct-acting antivirals to improve efficacy.

c.walk_why: Scheduling a follow-up in 6 months without initiating therapy would be the wrong decision in this case. The laboratory studies suggest an active chronic hepatitis infection genotype 1, which should be treated immediately with the appropriate combination of direct-acting antivirals for 12 weeks.

d.walk_why: Sofosbuvir and velpatasvir, both direct-acting antivirals, are the first-line treatment for a chronic hepatitis C infection (genotypes 2 and 3). However, this patient has an infection with hepatitis C virus genotype 1 and the combination of sofosbuvir and velpatasvir is not indicated in his case.

e.walk_why: Interferons are signaling proteins that belong to the innate host defense and may be used for treating certain diseases. In particular, peginterferon alpha is a pegylated interferon (pegylation delays the onset of action of interferons) that is used to treat a variety of diseases (e.g., Kaposi sarcoma, malignant melanoma, chronic hepatitis B). The combination of peginterferon alpha with ribavirin may also be administered in cases of chronic hepatitis C infection (especially genotypes 2 and 3). However, this patient has an infection with hepatitis C virus genotype 1. Therefore, peginterferon alpha and ribavirin are not indicated in his case.

f.walk_why: Sofosbuvir and ledipasvir, both direct-acting antivirals, are the first-line treatment for chronic hepatitis C infection of genotypes 1, 4, 5, and 6. Treatment of chronic hepatitis C infection depends on viral genotype, history of antiviral treatment, and the degree of liver fibrosis. The duration of treatment is typically 12 weeks. This patient had a severe car accident back in the 1980’s, at which time he probably received blood transfusions. However, testing of donor blood was introduced in 1992. This event is the most likely explanation of how the patient was infected with HCV, especially considering he has never used intravenous illicit drugs, which is considered one of the most important risk factors for HCV infection.
f.walk_but: In addition to the recommended medications, vaccinations for hepatitis A and B should be administered as well.

questions.subject: Infectiology and hygiene
questions.render_question:
A 43-year-old man comes to the physician because of nasal congestion and fatigue for 12 days. During this period, he has had fevers and severe pain over his cheeks. His nasal discharge was initially clear, but it has turned yellowish over the last couple of days. He has no visual complaints. He has been taking an over-the-counter nasal decongestant and acetaminophen without much relief. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. He underwent an appendectomy 23 years ago. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His current medications include metformin, sitagliptin, and enalapril. He appears tired. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 96/min, and blood pressure is 138/86 mm Hg. Examination shows purulent discharge in the nose and pharynx and normal appearing ears. The left maxillary sinus is tender to palpation. Laboratory studies show:













 Hemoglobin  14.6 g/dL Leukocyte count 10,800/mm3
 Platelet count  263,000/mm3
 ESR 22 mm/hr Serum Glucose 112 mg/dL 
 Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.render_hint: Acute viral rhinosinusitis usually presents with watery nasal discharge, fever, headaches, and facial pain over the affected sinuses. In case of bacterial superinfection, the discharge usually becomes mucopurulent and/or has a course longer than 9 days. This patient most likely had a viral infection first and is now presenting with a bacterial rhinosinusitis.

a.walk_why: Amphotericin B is an antifungal agent used to treat and prevent severe fungal infections such as aspergillosis, candidiasis, coccidioidomycosis, and histoplasmosis. Fungal sinusitis (e.g., caused by Aspergillus species) is rare and usually only occurs in immunocompromised patients. It is, however, unlikely in this patient and a different treatment is more appropriate at this time.

b.walk_why: Levofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic used to treat a variety of bacterial infections, including respiratory tract infections and urinary tract infections. It is considered a second-line antibiotic in the treatment of acute bacterial sinusitis and should not be the next step in the management of this patient.
b.walk_but: Treatment with a second-line antibiotic such as levofloxacin, moxifloxacin, cefuroxime, or clindamycin is indicated in patients who fail to respond to first-line therapy within 72 hours, have symptoms that persist more than two weeks after the initiation of therapy, or that may have been exposed to highly resistant organisms.

c.walk_why: Loratadine is a histamine H1 antagonist used to treat allergic rhinitis and urticaria. It is not indicated for the treatment of acute bacterial rhinosinusitis.
c.walk_but: Antihistamines are often used in the treatment of viral rhinosinusitis, as they have a drying effect on the nasal mucosa. However, there is no data on their efficacy in treating viral sinusitis, and over-drying of the mucosa can lead to irritation and additional discomfort.

d.walk_why: Reassurance and supportive treatment with antipyretics, analgesics, and nasal decongestants are usually sufficient in the treatment of patients with viral rhinosinusitis. However, because this patient has had symptoms for more than 10 days and a mucopurulent discharge suggestive of a bacterial infection, a different treatment is indicated.
d.walk_but: If this patient had presented with his initial symptoms, including watery nasal discharge, at less than 10-day duration, this answer would have been correct.

e.answer: CT scan of the paranasal sinuses
e.walk_why: A CT scan of the paranasal sinuses is not routinely performed in acute sinusitis. It may be used in unclear cases, if complications occur, to rule out neoplasms, or preoperatively in patients with chronic sinusitis (e.g., who are undergoing restoration of sinus ventilation).
e.walk_but: If a CT scan was performed in this patient, it would most likely show soft tissue swelling, mucoperiosteal thickening, and air-fluid levels.

f.walk_why: X-ray of the sinuses is usually not recommended in acute sinusitis because it does not help to differentiate between etiologies, and findings from it rarely influence the choice of treatment. It is only used in unclear cases or if complications occur.
f.walk_but: If an X-ray was performed in this patient, it would most likely show decreased transparency of the sinus and air-fluid levels.

g.walk_why: Amoxicillin-clavulanic acid is a penicillin antibiotic combined with a β-lactamase inhibitor that is used to treat a number of bacterial infections, particularly respiratory tract infections. It is considered the first-line treatment for acute bacterial sinusitis and is, therefore, the appropriate treatment for this patient.
g.walk_but: In addition to antibiotic treatment, the patient should receive antipyretic and analgesic therapy and be advised to rest and drink sufficient amounts of fluid.

questions.subject: OB/Gyn
questions.render_question: A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of vaginal discharge for 4 days. She has no pain or pruritus. Menses occur at regular 27-day intervals and last 5 days. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. She is sexually active with two male partners and uses a diaphragm for contraception. She had a normal pap smear 3 months ago. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 115/75 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows a malodorous gray vaginal discharge. The pH of the discharge is 5.0. Microscopic examination of the vaginal discharge shows clue cells and no leukocytes. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.render_hint: Based on the description of the vaginal discharge, its elevated pH value, and the microscopic findings, this patient most likely has bacterial vaginosis.

a.walk_why: Neisseria gonorrhoeae is the bacterium that causes gonorrhea. Gonorrhea also presents with vaginal discharge, but the discharge is typically odorless, purulent, and creamy. The patient is also lacking symptoms of dysuria, dyspareunia, and intermenstrual bleeding, which are typical accompanying features.

b.walk_why: Trichomonas vaginalis is a protozoan parasite and one of the etiologic agents of vulvovaginitis. Although T. vaginalis would cause a malodorous vaginal discharge with a pH > 4.5, the discharge is usually yellow-green and frothy. Additionally, vulvovaginitis due to T. vaginalis presents with pruritus, and the microscopic examination of the discharge would instead show flagellated protozoa.

c.walk_why: Infection with Chlamydia trachomatis is one of the most common sexually transmitted diseases in the US and a common cause of female infertility. C. trachomatis infection is often asymptomatic, but if discharge occurs, it is usually odorless and purulent. Clue cells are not associated with C. trachomatis, and instead it is usually diagnosed via nucleic acid amplification tests.

d.walk_why: Candida albicans is a fungus and a common cause of vulvovaginitis. Even though C. albicans also causes vaginal discharge, it is typically odorless, white, and crumbly, and the vaginal pH would be normal (< 4.5). Additional symptoms of infection with C. albicans include intense pruritus and a burning sensation in the vagina. Microscopic examination of the discharge would show pseudohyphae upon application of potassium hydroxide.

e.walk_why: Gardnerella vaginalis is an anaerobic bacterium that causes bacterial vaginosis. The condition is usually asymptomatic, but may present with vaginal discharge as seen in this patient. There are two characteristic diagnostic findings: Clue cells (epithelial cells covered with bacteria) seen on a wet mount preparation and a positive Whiff test. The Whiff test consists of applying potassium hydroxide to a slide with vaginal discharge, and is positive if this causes a fishy or amine odor.

f.walk_why: Escherichia coli is a cause of vaginitis, specifically aerobic vaginitis. E. coli vaginitis is characterized by vaginal discharge and an increase in the vaginal pH (> 4.5), just as in this patient. However, discharge caused by E. coli is usually odorless, yellowish, and presents with pruritus.

questions.subject: Infectiology and hygiene
questions.render_question: A 67-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive burning pain and intermittent “electrical shocks” in his right chest for 3 months. Over the last 2 weeks, the pain has increased to an extent that he can no longer tolerate clothing on the affected area. Three months ago, he had a rash around his right nipple and axilla that resolved a week later. The patient had a myocardial infarction 2 years ago. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus. He is sexually active with one female partner, and they do not use contraception. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 47 years and drinks one beer daily. Medications include aspirin, simvastatin, metoprolol, ramipril, and metformin. He is 176 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 95 kg (210 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. His temperature is 36.9°C (97.9°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 150/95 mm Hg. Examination shows increased sensation to light touch over the right chest. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.render_hint: This patient most likely had a painful rash in a dermatome-like distribution involving one side of the body, which is suggestive of a herpes zoster infection. Following the infection, the patient developed intense pain and an increasing skin sensitivity in the same area for over 3 months. Taken together, these features suggest post-herpetic neuralgia following herpes zoster infection. Postherpetic neuralgia (PHN) is described as attacks of acute, intense pain, persisting for at least 3 months in an area previously affected by the rash. PHN occurs in 10–15% of herpes zoster cases.

a.walk_why: Sublingual nitrates, vasodilating agents, may be used to treat patients with angina pectoris or hypertensive pulmonary edema. Although this patient has a history of ischemic heart disease and currently presents with burning pain on the right side of his chest, the pain seen in patients with angina pectoris is typically an acute retrosternal burning pain potentially radiating to the jaw and/or neck and left arm. However, this patient has persistent pain that occured in association with a skin rash, which makes angina pectoris less likely.

b.walk_why: Oral tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) may be used to treat major depressive disorder, fibromyalgia, and obsessive compulsive disorder. They are also the first-line medications for postherpetic neuralgia. However, they should not be administered in this patient because of his history of myocardial infarction, as they may prolong the QRS and/or QT segment, which may lead to arrhythmias. Acceptable alternatives include anticonvulsive agents and second-line options as topical capsaicin, opioids, and intrathecal glucocorticoid injections.

c.walk_why: Topical capsaicin, the compound in chili peppers that makes them hot, may be administered in patients with postherpetic neuralgia. However, they are not the first-line treatment for this condition. This patient should be treated with an anticonvulsive agent instead.

d.walk_why: Famciclovir, an antiviral, may be used to treat herpes simplex and varicella zoster virus infections. It is typically administered within 72 hours of the onset of herpes zoster infection (shingles). Shingles is characterized by an erythematous maculopapular rash that quickly evolves into vesicular lesions involving 1–3 dermatomes on one side of the body. This patient most likely had shingles. However, he is now presenting with symptoms suggestive of postherpetic neuralgia.

e.walk_why: Acyclovir, an antiviral, may be used to treat herpes simplex and varicella zoster virus infections. It can administered within 72 hours of the onset of herpes zoster infection (shingles). Shingles is typically characterized by a erythematous maculopapular rash that quickly evolves into vesicular lesions involving 1–3 dermatomes on one side of the body. This patient most likely had shingles. However, he is now presenting with symptoms suggestive of postherpetic neuralgia.

f.walk_why: Intrathecal glucocorticoids may be administered in patients with postherpetic neuralgia. However, they are not the first-line treatment for this condition. This patient should be treated with an anticonvulsive agent instead.

g.walk_why: Gabapentin, an anticonvulsant, may be used to treat partial (focal) seizures. Gabapentin is also one of the treatment options for neuropathic pain and thus for postherpetic neuralgia. While tricyclic antidepressants are generally considered a first-line treatment for postherpetic neuralgia, they should be given with caution in a patient with pre-existing heart disease (the patient has a history of a myocardial infarction), because they may prolong the QRS and/or QT segment, and thus may lead to arrhythmias. Therefore, an alternative like gabapentin (or pregabalin) is the appropriate medication in this particular patient.

questions.subject: Gastroenterology
questions.render_question:
A 37-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because her eyes have had a yellow discoloration and she has had dark urine for the past 3 days. She has also had fever, itching, and severe fatigue. She reports having symptoms of the stomach flu a week ago, which resolved with over-the-counter medication. She does not have diarrhea but says her stools are whitish in appearance. She has no personal history of serious illness. Her last menstrual period was a week ago. She does not smoke and drinks an average of two beers on weekends. She does not use illicit drugs. She has been sexually active with the same partner for 12 years and uses condoms consistently. She works as a flight attendant for an international airline. She appears ill. Her temperature is 39.3°C (102.7°F), pulse is 64/min, and blood pressure is 132/82 mm Hg. Examination shows scleral icterus, excoriation marks over her extremities, and parched lips. The liver is tender on palpation; there is no splenomegaly. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. Laboratory studies show:































 Hemoglobin  11.6 g/dL Leukocyte count 10,300/mm3
 Platelet count  256,000/mm3
 ESR 19 mm/hr Prothrombin time  13 seconds Serum Urea nitrogen 28 mg/dL Glucose 89 mg/dL Creatinine  0.7 mg/dL Bilirubin Total 8 mg/dL Direct  4 mg/dL ALP 80 U/L AST 312 U/L ALT 569 U/L 
 An ultrasound of the abdomen shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnostic finding?
questions.render_hint: The combination of scleral icterus, dark urine, and pale stools with fever, hyperbilirubinemia, and raised transaminases make acute hepatitis the most likely diagnosis. The patient travels frequently to foreign countries where hepatitis A is possibly endemic.

a.walk_why: Anti-mitochondrial antibodies are highly suggestive of primary biliary cirrhosis (PBC). PBC is a chronic cholangitis that may present with extensive pruritus and fatigue and leads to liver cirrhosis and cholestasis in later stages. Lab findings characteristically show elevated conjugated bilirubin and γ-GT, whereas transaminases are typically within normal limits. This patient shows signs of acute liver inflammation and infection (fever, elevated transaminases and unconjugated bilirubin), which make the diagnosis of PBC very unlikely.
a.walk_but: PBC classically affects women 35–60 years of age, and the patient in this vignette does fall within this range.

b.walk_why: Detection of anti-HAV IgG indicates a former infection with or a past vaccination against hepatitis A. In general, immunoglobulins of the IgG class are not the first antibodies produced by the immune system in response to acute infections and only appear some time after the initial infection. This patient’s presentation is consistent with acute hepatitis A infection for a week, which would not be enough time for IgG to develop.

c.walk_why: Detection of anti-HEV IgG indicates an infection with hepatitis E in the past. In general, immunoglobulins of the IgG class are not the first antibodies produced by the immune system in response to acute infections and only appear some time after the initial infection. This patient’s presentation is consistent with acute hepatitis infection for a week, which would not be enough time for IgG to develop. Additionally, hepatitis E is less common than other types of viral hepatitis.

d.walk_why: HBsAg is a surface antigen of the hepatis B virus (HBV) that indicates active hepatitis B infection. Patients with an acute hepatitis B infection may present with acute hepatitis similarly to this case, but it is often subclinical. In many cases, infection persists and leads to chronic hepatitis years later. HBV may be transmitted sexually, parenterally (e.g., needlestick injury), or perinatally. This patient does not have risk factors (e.g., multiple sex partners, exposure to HBV-infected persons or IV drug use) for any of these modes of transmission, making hepatitis B an unlikely diagnosis.

e.walk_why: This patient has acute viral hepatitis, which was most likely caused by the hepatitis A virus (HAV). Anti-HAV IgM are the first immunoglobulins produced in an immune response against HAV and are used as a confirmatory test for hepatitis A. HAV is transmitted via the fecal-oral route, usually by ingestion of undercooked contaminated food (esp. raw shellfish) and is endemic in many tropical and subtropical regions. This patient works as a flight attendant traveling to foreign countries where hepatitis A might be endemic, which puts her at risk for exposure.
e.walk_but: Hepatitis E presents similarly to hepatitis A, is also transmitted via the fecal-oral route, and is endemic in many tropical and subtropical countries. Infection with hepatitis A is more common, however.

f.walk_why: Perinuclear anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (p-ANCA) can be found in several autoimmune diseases, including primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC). PSC is a progressive inflammation of the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts, which is associated with ulcerative colitis in approx. 90% of cases. Patients are often asymptomatic but may also develop signs of cholestasis and cirrhosis in later stages of the disease. Markedly raised alkaline phosphatase are typical of the disease. This patient shows signs of cholestasis but her alkaline phosphatase is not elevated and she shows no signs of underlying ulcerative colitis, which makes PSC unlikely.

questions.subject: Infectiology and hygiene
questions.render_question: A previously healthy 2-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother after she noticed multiple painless, nonpruritic papules on her abdomen. The child attends daycare three times per week, and this past week one child was reported to have similar lesions. Her immunizations are up-to-date. Her brother had chickenpox one month ago. She is at the 50th percentile for height and the 60th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows several flesh-colored, non-tender, pearly papules with central umbilication on the abdomen and extremities. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.render_hint: The patient’s lesions are typical of those caused by a poxvirus.

a.walk_why: Keratoacanthoma is a low-grade tumor that commonly affects the elderly. It grows rapidly (within 2–3 months) in areas of skin exposed to the sun. Examinations show a round erythematous nodule with central crater. Based on the patient’s age (2 years old), the description of the skin lesions, and the recent onset of the lesions, this patient most likely has a different underlying pathology.

b.walk_why: Lichen planus is a chronic inflammatory disease of unknown origin that is characterized by different types of lesions involving the skin and mucosa in individuals between 30–60 years of age. The most common lesions are plaques or papules that are pruritic, polygonal, planar (flat-topped), and purple (the 6 P´s), which typically occur on the wrists, lower extremities, and genitoanal region. Pattern of white lines on the lesion’s surface (Wickham’s striae) may also be seen. However, the skin lesions in this case are flesh-colored and they do not have irregular borders or Wickham’s striae, which makes the diagnosis of cutaneous lichen planus unlikely.

c.walk_why: In the case of insect bites (e.g., mosquito or flea), lesions are typically pruritic and physical examination most often reveals erythematous papules at the site of the bite. The patient does not have any of these findings, which makes the diagnosis of insect bites less likely.

d.walk_why: Verruca vulgaris (common warts) are caused by human papilloma virus (HPV). They are rough, scaly papules or plaques that may sometimes have a cauliflower-like appearance. They are typically located on the hands, feet, and knees. However, the patient’s skin lesions are pearly papules with a central umbilication and they are located on the abdomen, allowing verruca vulgaris to be ruled out.

e.walk_why: Molluscum contagiosum is a common localized skin infection caused by the molluscum contagiosum virus (a DNA poxvirus) that typically affects children < 5 years of age. The lesions are nontender, flesh-colored, pearly, dome-shaped papules with central umbilication. They are usually 2–5 mm in diameter and commonly occur on the trunk, face, and genitalia. Because spontaneous remission usually occurs within 6–9 months, treatment is often unnecessary.
e.walk_but: Molluscum contagiosum also occurs in adults, particularly in those with immunosuppression (e.g., HIV) and/or if it has been sexually transmitted.

f.walk_why: Folliculitis is a localized inflammation of the hair follicle or sebaceous glands. It is primarily caused by Staphylococcus aureus and it is characterized by erythema, tender papules, and/or pustules at the site of hair follicles. However, the patient’s papules are non-tender and the vignette does not mention any association with hair follicles.

g.walk_why: Chickenpox (varicella) is an infection caused by the varicella-zoster virus (VZV) that occurs most frequently during childhood. It presents with a rash that is characterized by the simultaneous manifestation of macules, papules, vesicles, and crusts. The rash starts on the trunk, spreading to the face, scalp, and extremities and causing severe pruritus and fever. However, the patient’s rash is not pruritic and she does not have any further symptoms, which makes the diagnosis of chickenpox unlikely.
g.walk_but: As the name indicates, the VZV is also responsible for Herpes zoster (shingles) following virus reactivation, which would present with pain and a subsequent strip of vesicular erruption along a dermatome. Reactivation is generally triggered by immunosuppression and is most common in the elderly.

questions.subject: Infectiology and hygiene
questions.render_question:
A 19-year-old man comes to the physician because of fatigue, fever, body aches, headache, and sore throat for 1 week. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He is sexually active with one female partner and they use condoms consistently. His temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F), pulse is 99/min, and blood pressure is 110/72 mm Hg. Examination shows enlarged, erythematous, and exudative tonsils, as well as palatal petechiae and bilateral posterior auricular lymphadenopathy. The spleen tip is palpated 2 cm below the left costal margin. Laboratory studies show:





















 Hemoglobin  15 g/dL Leukocyte count 11500/mm3
 Segmented neutrophils 52% Band forms  2% Basophils 0.5% Eosinophils 1% Lymphocytes 41% Monocytes 3.5% Serum Heterophile antibody test positive 
 Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.render_hint: This patient's presentation of fever, fatigue, myalgia/arthralgia, headache, and bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy are consistent with both infectious mononucleosis and mononucleosis-like syndrome. However, splenomegaly, lymphocytosis, and the positive heterophile agglutination (Monospot test) indicate infectious mononucleosis (IM) as the cause of his symptoms.

a.walk_why: IM is caused by Epstein-Barr virus (human herpes virus 4) and it typically affects individuals younger than 30 years of age. Transmission frequently occurs via saliva ("kissing disease"). Clinical suspicion of IM is confirmed with a monospot test, which uses RBCs from horses to detect heterophile antibodies produced in response to Epstein-Barr virus infection. Treatment is symptomatic.
a.walk_but: EBV is also an onchogenic virus that can rarely cause Burkitt's lymphoma, nasopharyngeal carcinoma, or oral hairy leukoplakia.

b.walk_why: Acute human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection often presents as a mononucleosis-like syndrome, but this patient has no reported risk factors for HIV infection (e.g., several sexual partners, inconsistent use of condoms) and the diagnosis of IM has already been established.

c.walk_why: Cytomegalovirus (human herpes virus 5) infection may present as a mononucleosis-like syndrome, but more than 90% of affected individuals remain asymptomatic. Regardless, CMV is not the cause of IM.

d.walk_why: Streptococcus pyogenes (group A streptococci) may cause acute tonsillitis, which is characterized by fever, sore throat, dysphagia, a swollen pharynx, tonsillar exudates, and painful cervical lymphadenopathy. Although the presentation in this case is similar to that of acute tonsillitis, the diagnosis of IM has already been established.

e.walk_why: Toxoplasmosis is a disease caused by the parasite Toxoplasma gondii. Transmission occurs through ingestion of cysts present in, for example, raw meat or cat feces. It may present with mononucleosis-like symptoms, especially in immunocompetent patients. But the vignette does not mention any risk factors for acquiring toxoplasmosis, and a diagnosis of IM has already been established.

questions.subject: Infectiology and hygiene
questions.render_question: A 24-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because she has had dyspnea and palpitations occurring with mild exertion for the past 8 days. The symptoms originally quickly subsided following activity cessation, but have become worse and now last up to 45 minutes. The patient returned from a summer camping trip in Wisconsin 6 weeks ago. She has no history of serious illness. Her father suffered from a myocardial infarction at the age of 56. She drinks two to four beers on social occasions and occasionally smokes marijuana. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 47/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 150/70 mm Hg. A resting ECG shows sinus rhythm with repeated cycles of continuous PR interval prolongation until a QRS complex is absent before the cycle resets. Serology testing confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.render_hint: The ECG strip shows progressively longer PR intervals before a QRS is dropped and resets the cycle, which indicates a Mobitz type I 2nd-degree AV block (Wenckebach). Based on the history of a camping trip in the Midwest and the positive serology testing, early disseminated Lyme disease is the most likely cause for this patient's symptoms and the finding of AV block.

a.walk_why: Vitamin B1 (thiamine) supplementation may be indicated in the case of thiamine deficiency, which can cause wet beriberi. Wet beriberi is characterized by high-output cardiac failure (dilated cardiomyopathy), cardiomegaly, and edema. Thiamine deficiency typically occurs in cases of chronic alcohol consumption, malnutrition, and starvation. The vignette does not mention any of these risk factors nor edema. In this case of lyme carditis, another therapy is indicated.
a.walk_but: Similarly, thiamine deficiency can cause dry beriberi, which is characterized mainly by neurological symptoms resulting from damaged peripheral nerves.

b.walk_why: Beta blockers have negative inotropic, dromotropic, and chronotropic effects, which typically lead to decreased blood pressure and decreased oxygen consumption by the heart and can thus be used to treat hypertension and heart failure. Beta blockers would actually worsen the patient’s bradycardia (her pulse is 47/min) and are contraindicated if there is an AV block. In the case of lyme carditis, another form of therapy is indicated that treats the underlying cause.

c.walk_why: A permanent pacemaker implantation is not usually necessary to treat an AV block caused by Lyme carditis. Instead, another form of therapy is indicated that treats the underlying cause.
c.walk_but: Severe cases (e.g., Mobitz type II 2nd-degree AV block , 3rd degree AV block) or hemodynamically unstable patients may require temporary pacemaker implantation, however.

d.walk_why: Atropine, a muscarinic antagonist, may be indicated in cases of bradycardia. However, the patient is young, hemodynamically stable, and her symptoms are not severe. Furthermore, she has an AV block associated with early disseminated Lyme disease, so it is important to first treat the underlying cause. Additionally, atropine affects the sinus node as opposed to the AV node. Atropine is therefore not the appropriate medication in this patient.

e.walk_why: Intravenous ceftriaxone, a third generation cephalosporin, is the first-line treatment for Lyme carditis associated with arrhythmias and other manifestations of disseminated Lyme disease, which typically occurs 3–10 weeks after a tick bite. Although no tick bite nor signs of early localized Lyme disease (especially erythema chronica migrans) were reported, a clinican should by highly suspicious of Lyme carditis in a young patient presenting with palpitations, dyspnea, and Mobitz type I 2nd-degree AV block 6 weeks after a camping trip to a Lyme disease-endemic area. Diagnosis should be confirmed via serology before beginning antibiotic therapy.
e.walk_but: After outdoor activities in areas endemic for Lyme disease, disseminated Lyme disease should be ruled out as the cause of cardiac, neurological, and joint problems even if there is no , especially because erythema chronicum migrans only occurs in approx. 80% of infected individuals.

f.walk_why: Oral amoxicillin, a beta-lactam antibiotic, is used to treat localized and some manifestations of early disseminated lyme disease (including mild carditis) in patients < 8 years old and in pregnant and lactating women. However, in the case of lyme carditis with a 2nd-degree AV block, another form of therapy is indicated.

g.walk_why: Oral doxycycline, a tetracycline, is used to treat patients with localized and some manifestations of early disseminated lyme disease, including mild carditis. However, in the case of lyme carditis with a 2nd-degree AV block, another form of therapy is indicated.

questions.subject: Infectiology and hygiene
questions.render_question: A 15-year-old girl comes to the physician because of a sore throat and subjective fevers for the past 2 weeks. She has been feeling lethargic and is unable to attend school. She has a history of multiple episodes of streptococcal pharyngitis treated with amoxicillin. She immigrated with her family to the United States from China 10 years ago. Her father died of lung cancer at 56 years of age. She appears thin. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 97/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Examination shows pharyngeal erythema and enlarged tonsils with exudates and palatal petechiae. There is cervical lymphadenopathy. The spleen is palpated 2 cm below the left costal margin. Her hemoglobin concentration is 12 g/dL, leukocyte count is 14,100/mm3 with 54% lymphocytes (12% atypical lymphocytes), and platelet count is 280,000/mm3. A heterophile agglutination test is positive. The underlying cause of this patient’s symptoms is most likely to increase the risk of which of the following conditions?
questions.render_hint: This girl has fever, sore throat, pharyngeal erythema, enlarged tonsils, cervical lymphadenopathy, and splenomegaly. Lymphocytosis and the positive heterophile antibody test confirm that this patient's infectious mononucleosis is due to Epstein-Barr virus.

a.walk_why: Glomerulonephritis may occur as a complication following an infection (e.g., after streptococcal infection). Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis most commonly affects children and patients > 60 years of age. It occurs approx. 10–30 days following an acute infection with group A β-hemolytic streptococci (esp. after streptococcal pharyngitis). Although this patient has sore throat, pharyngeal erythema, enlarged tonsils, and a history of recurrent streptococcal pharyngitis, she presents with splenomegaly and has a positive heterophile agglutination test, which indicates infectious mononucleosis instead.

b.walk_why: Necrotizing retinitis is a potential complication of cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection in immunocompromised patients. More than 90% of individuals infected with CMV remain asymptomatic. But CMV also can cause a mononucleosis-like syndrome (CMV mononucleosis). Similar to infectious mononucleosis, symptoms include fever, malaise, myalgia/arthralgia, fatigue, headache, and sore throat. However, the monospot (heterophile antibody) test would be negative.

c.walk_why: Rheumatic fever is a delayed inflammatory sequela of group A β-hemolytic streptococcal (GAS) pharyngitis that typically affects individuals 5–15 years of age within 2–4 weeks of infection. Although this patient has sore throat, pharyngeal erythema, enlarged tonsils, and a history of recurrent streptococcal pharyngitis, she presents with splenomegaly and has a positive heterophile agglutination test, which indicates infectious mononucleosis instead.

d.walk_why: Pneumonia is a potential complication of cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection, particularly for immunocompromised individuals (e.g., HIV or post-transplantation). More than 90% of individuals infected with CMV remain asymptomatic. But CMV also can cause a mononucleosis-like syndrome (CMV mononucleosis). Similar to infectious mononucleosis, symptoms include fever, malaise, myalgia/arthralgia, fatigue, headache, and sore throat. However, the monospot (heterophile antibody) test would be negative.

e.walk_why: Kaposi's sarcoma is a malignant spindle cell tumor that originates from endothelial cells and occurs predominantly in immunosuppressed patients (typically seen in AIDS patients). It is not caused by Epstein-Barr virus (human herpes virus 4, HHV-4), but a close relative, the human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8). However, both HHV-4 and HHV-8 are oncoviruses that can lead to malignancies.
e.walk_but: From a clinical point of view, an acute human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection and infectious mononucleosis cannot be easily differentiated (in this patient, pharyngeal erythema and exudative enlarged tonsils would favor the diagnosis of IM), so only serology testing (here the positive heterophile agglutination test) can lead to the right diagnosis.

f.walk_why: Intracranial calcifications are an imaging (e.g., CT scan) finding and can occur in the context of aging or in association with certain diseases (e.g., toxoplasmosis). Toxoplasmosis in immunocompetent patients (with the exception of the newborn) is mainly asymptomatic, but may lead to mononucleosis-like syndrome with bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy. Cerebral toxoplasmosis is in fact a potential complication of toxoplasmosis, but it affects immunocompromised patients (esp. AIDS patients) and is not characterized by intracranial calcifications.
f.walk_but: Toxoplasmosis also belongs to the TORCH infections, which is transmitted via the placenta from mother to fetus.

g.walk_why: Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is a potential complication of infectious mononucleosis caused by Epstein-Barr virus (EBV). Nasopharyngeal carcinoma typically affects individuals 45–75 years of age and is common among people of Asian, North African, and Mediterranean decent. EBV, an oncovirus, may also lead to further malignancies such as Burkitt lymphoma and hairy leukoplakia (typically affecting immunocompromised patients).

questions.subject: Pediatrics
questions.render_question: A 4-month-old African-American infant is brought to the pediatrician for a well-baby check up. He was born at term through a normal vaginal delivery and has been well since. His 4-year old brother has sickle-cell disease. He is exclusively breastfed and receives vitamin D supplements. His immunizations are up-to-date. He appears healthy. His length is at the 70th percentile and weight is at the 75th percentile. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. His mother has heard reports of sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS) being common in his age group and would like to hear more information about it. Which of the following is the most important recommendation to prevent this condition?

a.answer: Cardiorespiratory monitoring of the baby at home
a.walk_why: The American Academy of Pediatrics recommends against the use of cardiorespiratory monitoring devices for SIDS risk reduction. There is no evidence that such devices contribute to reducing the risk of SIDS.

b.answer: Have the baby sleep in supine position
b.walk_why: Having the baby sleep in supine position is a strategy recommended by the American Academy of Pediatrics for reducing the risk of SIDS. Several studies have shown that sleeping in the prone position is the most significant modifiable risk factor for SIDS. Although the mechanism is not clear, sleeping in the prone position seems to predispose children to suffocation.

c.answer: Have the baby sleep with the parent
c.walk_why: Bed-sharing is not regarded as a safe practice, according to recommendations of the American Academy of Pediatrics. Studies have shown that children sleeping near an adult are at increased risk for SIDS. Some features of adult beds, e.g., soft surfaces and additional bedding, may contribute to this risk.

d.answer: Avoid feeding the baby close to bedtime
d.walk_why: There is no association between the time at which a baby is fed and reduction of the risk of SIDS.

e.answer: Keep the baby warm with thick blankets
e.walk_why: Excessive swaddling may increase the risk of SIDS. Some studies show that the risk of SIDS increases with the amount of blankets or clothing. Swaddling is a safe and recommended practice in newborns. However, it should be discouraged among children beyond two months of age because it may increase the risk of suffocation if the baby rolls over.

f.answer: Make sure that no one smokes around the baby
f.walk_why: Exposing infants to secondhand smoke increases their risk of SIDS and should, therefore, be avoided. However, it is not the most important recommendation for SIDS prevention.

g.answer: Use soft bedding and pillows for the baby
g.walk_why: Soft bedding and pillows are factors that have been independently associated with increased risk of SIDS. Studies have shown up to a five-fold increase in risk of SIDS, possibly due to airflow obstruction.

questions.subject: Infectiology and hygiene
questions.render_question: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a cough for 2 days. The cough occurs as paroxysmal spells, with vomiting sometimes occurring afterwards. She takes a deep breath after these spells that makes a “whooping” sound. She has been unable to sleep well because of the cough. She had a runny nose and low-grade fever 1 week ago. She was admitted at the age of 9 months for bronchiolitis. Her immunizations are incomplete, as her parents are afraid of vaccine-related complications. She attends a daycare center but there have been no other children who have similar symptoms. She appears well. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Her hemoglobin concentration is 13.3 g/dL, leukocyte count is 41,000/mm3, platelet count is 230,000/mm3 and erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 31 mm/hr. An X-ray of the chest is unremarkable. The patient is at increased risk for which of the following complications?
questions.render_hint: Paroxysmal coughing spells followed by an inspiratory whoop and occasional vomiting is typical for pertussis and goes hand in hand with increased intra-alveolar pressure!

a.walk_why: Pericarditis is the inflammation of the pericardium that presents with chest pain and dyspnea. It is most commonly idiopathic or caused by viruses but can also occur in association with bacterial infections, neoplasms, collagen-vascular diseases (e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus), certain drugs (e.g., doxorubicin), radiation, trauma, or following acute myocardial infarction. However, Bordetella pertussis, the pathogen that causes pertussis, is not known to cause pericarditis.

b.walk_why: Hemolytic anemia is a condition characterized by the increased destruction of red blood cells and presents with jaundice and dark urine in addition to signs of anemia. The disease can be hereditary (e.g., sickle cell disease) or acquired (e.g., in association with infections). Known infectious causes of hemolytic anemia include Mycoplasma species and Clostridium perfringens. Bordetella pertussis, the pathogen that causes whooping cough, however, is not associated with hemolytic anemia.
b.walk_but: Mycoplasma pneumoniae is a common cause of atypical pneumonia (also for children). Patients typically present with a nonproductive cough and a low-grade fever. Diagnostic evaluation shows diffuse reticular opacities on chest X-ray. Atypical pneumonia is an important differential diagnosis and should be considered in this patient. However, the typical cough with a “whooping” sound makes pertussis more likely.

c.walk_why: Guillain-Barré syndrome is an immune-mediated neurological disorder that presents with progressive ascending paralysis. It most commonly occurs as a sequela of Campylobacter jejuni gastroenteritis but can present in association with other infections such as Mycoplasma pneumoniae, cytomegalovirus, or Epstein-Barr virus infection. Pertussis, however, is not associated with this condition.

d.walk_why: Hemoptysis is coughing up blood from the lower respiratory tract. It can be caused by a variety of conditions, including infectious diseases (e.g., tuberculosis), autoimmune diseases (e.g., Goodpasture syndrome), cardiac diseases (e.g., congestive heart failure), toxins (e.g., cocaine use), or airway trauma. Pertussis, however, is not a likely cause of hemoptysis.

e.walk_why: Pneumothorax is the accumulation of air within the pleural space that presents with sudden chest pain and dyspnea. Pertussis (whooping cough) is usually associated with severe bouts of coughing, leading to increased intrathoracic and intra-abdominal pressure and a subsequent risk of complications such as scleral hemorrhages, epistaxis, abdominal hernias, and pneumothorax. Other, more common complications of pertussis include apnea and secondary infections (e.g., otitis media).
e.walk_but: The pertussis vaccination is recommended for all children at 2, 4, 6, and 15–18 months, as well as 4–6 years and is routinely administered together with the diphtheria and tetanus vaccine (DTaP). The incidence of pertussis has significantly decreased since the introduction of the vaccine in the 1940s. However, there has been a steady increase in incidence over the past 40 years and epidemics occur every 2–5 years in the US. The reason for the recent increase in incidence is not fully understood but may be due to factors such as more sensitive diagnostic tests, decreased use of the pertussis vaccine, and genetic changes in the strains of pertussis.

f.walk_why: Asthma is an obstructive lung disease with a complex etiology that presents with attacks of dyspnea, coughing, and chest pain. Respiratory tract infections, allergens, and exercise can all trigger acute asthma attacks in genetically predisposed individuals. Childhood risk factors for persistent asthma include atopic dermatitis, allergic rhinitis, food allergies, and bronchiolitis requiring hospitalizations. While the patient’s history of hospitalization for bronchiolitis puts her at an increased risk of developing asthma, it is not a complication of pertussis.

questions.subject: Infectiology and hygiene
questions.render_question: A 20-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of an animal bite. He was hiking earlier that day when he was bitten by a raccoon. He says the attack was unprovoked and the animal ran away after the encounter. He was bitten by a stray dog when he was 11 years old and received postexposure prophylaxis for rabies at that time. His immunizations are up-to-date. His immunization record shows he received 3 doses of diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis vaccine as a child and a tetanus-diphtheria-acellular pertussis vaccination at the age of 16. He is in no apparent distress. His temperature is 98.4°F (36.9°C), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 124/75 mm Hg. He has a wound on his left lower extremity with actively bleeding puncture sites. The wound is thoroughly irrigated with normal saline and cleansed with antiseptic and a bandage is applied. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

a.walk_why: Even patients who have been vaccinated against rabies should be treated after being bitten by an animal that is a known wild reservoir for the virus.

b.walk_why: Rabies vaccination is given as standalone postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) in patients who have previously received the rabies vaccine. Since this patient already received rabies PEP (which consisted of both the rabies vaccine and immunoglobulin) at the age of 11, he should only receive the vaccine at this time. He was bitten in an unprovoked attack by an animal known to be a wild reservoir for rabies. In addition to wound cleaning and consideration of tetanus and antibiotic prophylaxis, rabies PEP is very important.

c.walk_why: Rabies immunoglobulin and vaccine constitute the rabies postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) for individuals who have not previously received the vaccine. However, this patient already received rabies PEP at the age of 11, which means he should only receive a simplified PEP regimen this time.

d.walk_why: A tetanus booster with Td or Tdap would only be indicated if the last vaccination was ≥ 5 years ago, which is not the case in this patient. Additionally, even patients who have been vaccinated against rabies should be treated after being bitten by an animal that is a known wild reservoir for the virus.

e.answer: Tetanus booster, rabies immunoglobulin, and vaccine
e.walk_why: Rabies immunoglobulin plus vaccine constitute the rabies postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) for individuals who have not previously received the vaccine. Active tetanus immunization with Td (tetanus, diphtheria) or Tdap (tetanus, diphtheria, pertussis) would be indicated if the last vaccination was ≥ 5 years ago, which is not the case in this patient.

f.walk_why: Rabies vaccination is given as standalone postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) in patients who have previously received the rabies vaccine, as this patient has. But active tetanus immunization with Td or Tdap would only be indicated if the last vaccination was ≥ 5 years ago, which is not the case in this patient.

g.walk_why: Rabies immunoglobulin is part of rabies postexposure prophylaxis (PEP), but it is generally administered with the rabies vaccine. Immunoglobulin alone is not a sufficient prophylaxis.

h.walk_why: Rabies immunoglobulin is part of rabies postexposure prophylaxis (PEP), but it is generally administered with the rabies vaccine. This patient already received rabies PEP at the age of 11 and should receive a simplified PEP regimen this time. Active tetanus immunization with Td or Tdap would be indicated if the last vaccination was ≥ 5 years ago, which is not the case in this patient.

questions.subject: Infectiology and hygiene
questions.render_question: A 26-year-old man comes to the physician because of high-grade fever and headache for 5 days. The headache is constant and feels like a tight band around his head. The patient has had generalized fatigue and nausea for 4 days. He also reports that his eyes hurt while looking at bright lights. He has been taking acetaminophen and using cold towels to help relieve his symptoms. He works as an assistant for a nature camp organization, but has been unable to go to work for 3 days. His immunization records are unavailable. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 108/74 mm Hg. He is oriented to time, place, and person. There is no rash or lymphadenopathy. Flexion of the neck results in flexion of the knee and hip. A lumbar puncture is done; cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows an opening pressure of 80 mm H20, erythrocyte count of 25/mm3, leukocyte count of 93/mm3 (78% lymphocytes), a glucose concentration of 64 mg/dL, and a protein concentration of 50 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.render_hint: This patient presents with fever, headache, photophobia, and a positive Brudzinski sign (flexion of the neck results in flexion of the knee and hip). Together with a moderately raised leukocyte count with predominantly lymphocytes, slightly raised protein and normal glucose concentrations in the cerebrospinal fluid indicate aseptic meningitis.

a.walk_why: Coxsackie virus, a nonenveloped picornavirus, may cause carditis, herpangina, and hand, foot, and mouth disease. Coxsackie virus is also a common cause of aseptic (viral) meningitis. This patient has CSF findings associated with a viral etiology, which favors an infection with coxsackie virus. Clinical features of viral and bacterial meningitis are very similar. However, bacterial meningitis has a highly acute course and can be fatal within hours or days, whereas viral meningitis generally has a less acute onset and is usually self-limiting within 7–10 days. Lumbar puncture followed by cerebrospinal fluid analysis (CSF) helps to differentiate between different etiologies of meningitis.
a.walk_but: Gram staining of the CSF is negative in viral meningitis, hence the name “aseptic” meningitis.

b.walk_why: Neisseria meningitidis, a gram-negative diplococci, may lead to meningitis, meningococcemia, and Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome. Neisseria meningitidis is also the second most common cause of bacterial meningitis in individuals 6–60 years of age. Based on the patient’s age and clinical features alone, he may have meningitis of a bacterial origin. However, cerebrospinal fluid findings in bacterial meningitis are typically characterized by increased protein, decreased glucose, and significant granulocytosis, which make the diagnosis of bacterial meningitis unlikely in this patient.

c.walk_why: Herpes simplex virus (HSV) can either be an oral (HSV-1) or a genital (HSV-2) type. HSV-1 may lead to stomatitis, herpes labialis, keratoconjunctivitis, and herpes simplex encephalitis (HSE), whereas HSV-2 predominantly causes herpes genitalis. HSE typically presents with a prodrome of headaches and fever, followed by sudden focal neurological deficits and altered mental status. Although the patient’s cerebrospinal fluid findings are consistent with meningitis of a viral origin, he does not present with focal neurological deficits, seizures, altered mental status, or behavioral changes, which make the diagnosis of HSE less likely.

d.walk_why: Borrelia burgdorferi, a spirochete, is transmitted to humans by ticks and causes Lyme disease. Lyme disease typically starts with an erythema migrans, which is followed by neurological symptoms (e.g., facial palsy), migratory arthralgia, and cardiac manifestations (e.g., myocarditis). Late disease is characterized by chronic arthritis and late neuroborreliosis with possible progressive encephalomyelitis and aseptic meningitis. The patient’s cerebrospinal fluid findings are compatible with a Borrelia burgdorferi infection. However, the patient has no history of a rash, arthritis, or cranial nerve involvement (facial palsy), which makes Lyme disease less likely.
d.walk_but: Advanced stages of Lyme disease can also cause aseptic meningitis.

e.walk_why: Streptococcus pneumoniae, a gram-positive diplococci, may lead to otitis media, sinusitis, and community-acquired pneumonia. It is also the most common cause of bacterial meningitis in individuals 6–60 years of age. Based on the patient’s age and clinical features, he may have meningitis of a bacterial origin. However, cerebrospinal fluid findings in bacterial meningitis are typically characterized by increased protein, decreased glucose, and significant granulocytosis, which make the diagnosis of bacterial meningitis unlikely in this patient.

f.walk_why: Mycobacterium tuberculosis, an acid-fast gram-positive bacilli, causes tuberculosis that commonly affects the lung. It can also disseminate and may lead to an infection of the meninges, tuberculous meningitis. Based on the patient’s clinical features alone, he may have tuberculous meningitis. However, cerebrospinal fluid findings in tuberculous meningitis are typically characterized by pleocytosis (not only lymphocytes, but also granulocytes and mononuclear cells). Furthermore, the patient lacks risk factors for having a tuberculous infection (no previous history of exposure to Mycobacterium tuberculosis; the patient is not from a country in which tuberculosis is endemic), which make the diagnosis of tuberculous meningitis less likely.

questions.subject: Infectiology and hygiene
questions.render_question: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 4-day history of fever, headache, earache, and sore throat that is worse when swallowing. He has not had a runny nose or cough. He had a similar problem 1 year ago for which he was prescribed amoxicillin, but after developing a skin rash and facial swelling he was switched to a different medication. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 75th percentile for height and the 50th percentile for weight. His temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 136/min, and respirations are 28/min. Examination of the oral cavity reveals a coated tongue, red uvula, and enlarged right tonsil covered by a whitish membrane. The jugulodigastric lymph nodes are enlarged and tender. A throat swab is taken for culture. What is the next most appropriate step in the management of this patient?
questions.render_hint: This child is presenting with fever, dysphagia, and an enlarged tonsil with exudates. These findings indicate acute bacterial tonsillitis, which is most commonly caused by Streptococcus pyogenes. He also appears to have had an allergic reaction to amoxicillin in the past.

a.walk_why: Macrolides such as erythromycin are antibiotics that inhibit bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 50S subunit of the ribosome. They are used for treating various conditions, including atypical pneumonia, upper respiratory infections, and are second-line for bacterial tonsillitis. This patient is presenting with tonsillitis that is likely of bacterial etiology, which would normally be treated with penicillin V. However, penicillins are contraindicated in this patient because of his past allergic reaction to another penicillin antibiotic (i.e., skin rash and facial swelling after taking amoxicillin). Thus, macrolides should be given instead.

b.walk_why: Cefixime is a 3rd generation cephalosporin that is used to treat uncomplicated urinary tract infections and exacerbations of chronic bronchitis. Cephalosporins are beta-lactam antibiotics that inhibit cell wall synthesis by blocking peptidoglycan cross-linking. 3rd generation cephalosporins have a wider gram-negative spectrum than those of the 1st and 2nd generation, but they do not provide the gram-positive coverage that penicillins or some macrolides do. They are therefore not the ideal choice for acute bacterial tonsillitis.
b.walk_but: Cefixime can also be used in the treatment of pharyngitis and tonsillitis but is not the first-line treatment.

c.walk_why: Azoles are antifungal agents that inhibit fungal ergosterol synthesis, thus impairing membrane synthesis. Fluconazole is used topically to treat local fungal infections such as candidiasis, and systemically to treat systemic mycoses such as cryptococcal meningitis in AIDS patients. The whitish membrane seen covering this patient’s tonsil could be a finding of oral Candida infection (i.e., thrush). However, in a healthy child with a fever and acute tonsillitis, it is more likely to be tonsillar exudates (i.e., a protein-rich fluid related to infection). Fungal infections are more common in immunosuppressed or systemically ill individuals.

d.walk_why: Total tonsillectomy is a surgical procedure in which the entire tonsils and tonsillar capsule are typically removed. This procedure is more commonly performed in adults than in children. Total tonsillectomy is an option in recurrent and chronic tonsillitis, and in cases of peritonsillar abscess. It is associated with a high risk of postoperative bleeding, and is therefore not suitable as the initial treatment in this patient, who is a child, has no signs of peritonsillar abscess (e.g., muffled speech and trismus), and has had an uncomplicated course up to now.

e.walk_why: Partial tonsillectomy (i.e., subtotal tonsillectomy) is a surgical procedure to remove only part of the tonsils and leave the tonsillar capsule intact. This procedure is carried out in children more often than adults, particularly in cases of sleep apnea secondary to tonsillar hypertrophy. Partial tonsillectomy is also an option in recurrent and chronic tonsillitis, or tonsillitis with peritonsillar abscess. However, it carries the usual risks associated with surgery (e.g., postoperative bleeding, infection, etc.) and is therefore not suitable as the initial treatment in this patient, who has no signs of peritonsillar abscess (e.g., muffled speech and trismus) and an uncomplicated course up to now.

f.walk_why: Penicillin V is a beta-lactam antibiotic that is mainly used to treat infections caused by gram-positive bacteria (Streptococcus pneumoniae, Streptococcus pyogenes, Actinomyces), including streptococcal skin infections and tonsillitis. S. pyogenes is the most common cause of bacterial tonsillitis and is uniformly sensitive to penicillin, making penicillin V the first-line treatment. However, given this patient’s history of allergic reaction to amoxicillin (i.e., skin rash and facial swelling), penicillin antibiotics are contraindicated.

questions.subject: OB/Gyn
questions.render_question: A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician because of yellow vaginal discharge, pruritus, and pain with urination for the past 6 days. Three weeks ago, she had an episode of acute bacterial rhinosinusitis that was treated with a 10-day course of amoxicillin. She has been sexually active with multiple male partners over the past year and uses condoms inconsistently; she has been taking an oral contraceptive for the past 2 years. She has no previous history of serious illness or sexually transmitted diseases. The patient drinks alcohol on the weekends and has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily since she was 15 years old. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 122/82 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. Pelvic examination shows erythema of the vulva and vagina and foul-smelling, frothy, yellow-green vaginal discharge. The pH of the discharge is 5.8. Bimanual examination is unremarkable. Further evaluation of this patient’s vaginal discharge is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.render_hint: Based on the prior antibiotic use, multiple sexual partners and the characteristic description of the vaginal discharge with an elevated pH value, this patient most likely has trichomoniasis.

a.walk_why: The whiff test is performed by adding potassium hydroxide to a mount containing vaginal discharge. It is positive if the test produces a fishy odor, which is highly characteristic of bacterial vaginosis. Unlike in this patient, bacterial vaginosis usually presents as a white or grey-colored discharge without any vulvovaginal erythema.
a.walk_but: The discharge in bacterial vaginosis also features an alkaline pH!

b.walk_why: Trichomonas vaginalis is an anaerobic, motile protozoan with flagella. Patients typically have foul-smelling, frothy, yellow-green, purulent vaginal discharge with a pH > 4.5. Transmission of this disease occurs through unprotected sex. Most patients remain asymptomatic.

c.walk_why: Pseudohyphae are loosely filamentous forms of fungi assumed by many yeasts, particularly Candida albicans, during growth. They are commonly seen on wet mounts of patients with vaginal yeast infections (vulvovaginal candidiasis), which are associated with odorless white, crumbly, and sticky vaginal discharge that may resemble cottage cheese. Pregnancy, antibiotic use, and immunosuppression are predisposing factors for vaginal thrush. Even though this patient had a course of amoxicillin, her discharge is foul-smelling and yellow-green, making a candidal infection very unlikely.

d.walk_why: Chlamydia is an obligate intracellular bacterium and the most common cause of sexually transmitted bacterial disease worldwide. Infection with chlamydia is often asymptomatic. If symptoms appear, they typically include (muco)purulent endocervical discharge and intermenstrual or postcoital bleeding, which this patient lacks. Furthermore, physical examination of the cervix often causes bleeding, whereas the bimanual examination of this patient was unremarkable.

e.walk_why: Gram-negative diplococci indicate infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae (gonorrhea). The disease is transmitted sexually and is usually asymptomatic in women. If symptoms arise, they typically include purulent, creamy vaginal discharge and intermenstrual bleeding but no erythema of the vulva.

questions.subject: Infectiology and hygiene
questions.render_question: A 53-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of worsening confusion and weakness in his left arm and leg for 2 days. He has also had fever and headache that began 5 days ago. He has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Two months ago, he underwent a laparoscopic cholecystectomy and recovered without any complications. His father died of colon cancer. His current medications include metformin and lisinopril. His temperature is 39.3°C (102.7°F), pulse is 103/min, and blood pressure is 128/78 mm Hg. He is confused and very agitated. His speech is incoherent and irrelevant. He is not oriented to person, place, or time. Nuchal rigidity is present. Neurologic examination shows left upper and lower extremity strength of 3/5 and normal strength on the right side. An ECG show no abnormalities. An MRI scan of the head is shown. Shortly after the MRI scan, the patient has a seizure and is admitted to the intensive care unit following administration of intravenous lorazepam. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.render_hint: The patient's history of acute fever, altered mental status, focal neurological deficits, and the MRI findings of a temporal hyperintense area (cMRT in T2) are highly suggestive of herpes simplex encephalitis (HSE). HSE should be treated immediately if suspected. Detection of HSV-DNA (via PCR) in the cerebrospinal fluid confirms the diagnosis.

images.title: Herpes simplex encephalitis
images.description: A coronal T2-weighted MR image of a 53-year-old patient's brain. The patient presented to the emergency department after fever and headache for 5 days with progressive confusion and weakness in the left arm and leg. In the medial area of the both temporal lobes, there is high signal intensity (green areas) that is more pronounced on the right. The right side also involves the insular cortex. The hyperintense signal is caused by cerebral edema, which is compressing the right lateral ventricle (arrows) via mass effect. Possible causes for these findings include limbic encephalitis, gliomatosis cerebri, prolonged status epilepticus, and HSV encephalitis. If HSV is suspected, cerebrospinal fluid should be conducted via lumbar puncture. If CSF analysis is inconclusive, the next step to confirm the diagnosis would be to obtain a biopsy of the area via aspiration to test for HSV DNA via PCR.
images.copyright: Source: “Hsv encephalitis.jpg” by Dr. Laughlin Dawes, Wikimedia Commons, licensed under CC BY 3.0. The supplementary image with overlays of relevant areas was adapted from the image mentioned above (© a22n Inc.).

a.walk_why: Ceftriaxone, a third generation cephalosporin, has many different indications (e.g., bacterial meningitis, gonorrhea), whereas vancomycin may be administered to treat serious Gram-positive infections (e.g., MRSA, Clostridium difficile). The combination of both medications is administered empirically if bacterial meningitis is suspected. Although fever, nuchal rigidity, and altered mental status may present with meningitis, the MRI findings and focal neurological deficits are not typical for meningitis.

b.walk_why: Recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rtPA), a thrombolytic, may be administered in the case of an early ischemic stroke (within 3 hours of the start of symptoms), an early myocardial infarct, or to treat severe pulmonary embolism. Although this patient presents with signs of ichemic stroke, based on the time frame alone, rtPA would be contraindicated in this patient. Additionally, the prodromal phase and 5-day fever would not be associated with stroke. Lastly, the normal ECG makes ischemic stroke even less likely since the condition is commonly caused by thromboembolism as a result of atrial fibrillation.
b.walk_but: Both ischemic stroke and HSV encephalitis are associated with focal symptoms, altered mental status, and fever. Both conditions are also associated with hyperintense areas in the temporal lobe. However, ischemic stroke most commonly affects the middle cerebral artery, which can result in changes to the temporal lobe and basal ganglia rather than just the posteromedial temporal lobe as seen here.

c.walk_why: Amphotericin B, an antifungal agent, may be indicated in cases of severe mycoses, including meningitis caused by the fungus Cryptococcus neoformans. Cryptococcal meningitis typically affects immunocompromised patients and is associated with subacute symptoms that develop over weeks. Although fever, nuchal rigidity, and altered mental status may present with meningitis, this patients symptoms developed acutely and there are no signs or history of immunosuppression. Additionally, the MRI findings and focal neurological deficits are not typical for meningitis.

d.walk_why: Acyclovir, an antiviral agent, may be used to treat herpes simplex and varicella-zoster virus infections. Intravenous acyclovir is the treatment of choice as soon as herpes simplex encephalitis (HSE) is suspected. HSE is typically characterized by a prodromal phase (fever, headache) followed by acute or subacute encephalopathy with symptoms of focal neurological deficits (such as the paresis exhibited by the patient), seizures, altered mental status, and behavioral changes. Whenever a patient presents with symptoms suggestive of HSV encephalitis, an MRI and lumbar puncture are indicated to confirm the suspected diagnosis.

e.walk_why: Ceftriaxone, a third generation cephalosporin, has many indications (e.g., bacterial meningitis, gonorrhea). Vancomycin may be administered to treat serious Gram-positive infections (e.g., MRSA, Clostridium difficile). Ampicillin, a beta-lactam antibiotic, is effective against Gram-positive and some Gram-negative infections. It is administered in combination with ceftriaxone and vancomycin as empirical therapy for suspected bacterial meningitis in groups of individuals more susceptible to Listeria monocytogenes, which includes newborns, elderly, and immunocompromised individuals. Based on the patient’s age, he is unlikely to have an infection with Listeria meningitis. Additionally, the MRI findings and focal neurological deficits are not typical for meningitis.

questions.subject: Infectiology and hygiene
questions.render_question:
A 44-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of progressive pain while swallowing. She has the feeling that food gets stuck in her throat and is harder to swallow than usual. She has a history of high-grade cervical dysplasia which was treated with conization 12 years ago. Four months ago, she was diagnosed with Graves’ disease and started on antithyroid therapy. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. She has had 8 lifetime sexual partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Her father died of stomach cancer. She has never smoked and drinks one glass of wine daily. She uses cocaine occasionally. Her current medications include methimazole and a vitamin supplement. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F). pulse is 75/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mm Hg. Examination of the oral cavity shows several white plaques that can be scraped off easily. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Laboratory studies show:































 Hemoglobin  11.9 g/dL Leukocyte count 12,200/mm3
 Platelet count  290,000/mm3
 Prothrombin time  12 seconds Partial thromboplastin time (activated) 38 seconds Serum pH  7.33 Na+
 135 mEq/L Cl-
 104 mEq/L K+
  4.9 mEq/L HCO3-
 24 mEq/L Blood urea nitrogen 13 mg/dL Glucose 110 mg/dL Creatinine  1.1 mg/dL HIV test  positive 
 In addition to starting antiretroviral therapy, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.render_hint: This patient has white plaques that are scraped off easily, indicating oral thrush. Additionally, her dysphagia is consistent with esophagitis. Together, oral thrush and esophagitis in a patient with a positive HIV test is most likely caused by Candida albicans.

a.walk_why: Esophagogastroduodenoscopy is an upper endoscopy used to examine the esophagus, stomach, and the first part of the duodenum. In a patient with clinical features of esophagitis and oral thrush on examination, optimal management would first involve the treatment of fungal organisms. If this patient’s symptoms were to persist even after treatment, the next step would be an esophagogastroduodenoscopy.

b.walk_why: Fluconazole is a first-generation triazole antifungal medication used against Candida, Cryptococcus, dermatophytes, and other dimorphic fungi. This patient has symptoms of esophagitis as well as oral thrush on examination. In HIV-positive patients, 50–70% of cases of esophagitis are caused by Candida albicans. Therefore, it is prudent to give this patient a trial of fluconazole to see if her symptoms improve. If her symptoms do not improve, she should undergo an upper endoscopy to rule out other causes of esophagitis.

c.walk_why: Nystatin is an antifungal drug used to treat candidal infections of the skin and vagina.
